item.title: Iran | Leader calls for show of force on the streets against US
item.description: Iran's supreme leader yesterday called on Iranians to use the 47th anniversary of the Islamic Revolution on Wednesday to demonstrate strength against the enemy, in a context of tensions with the United States. Since 1979, “foreign powers have always sought to reestablish the previous situation”, declared Ali Khamenei, in reference to external influence during the Pahlavi dynasty (1925-1979), an ally of the Americans, which was removed from power by the revolution. Led by the then 'ayatollah' Ruhollah Khomeini, Shiite fundamentalists established the Islamic Republic following the 1979 revolution, which deposed Mohammad Reza Pahlavi, the last shah of Iran, formally called Persia until 1935. “The power of a nation lies not so much in its missiles and planes, but in the will and resilience of its people,” said Khamenei, quoted by the France-Presse news agency (AFP). “Show it again and thwart the enemy’s plans,” said the supreme leader, calling on Iranians to participate in the anniversary of the revolution. “The presence of the people at the march and the expression of loyalty to the Islamic Republic will make the enemy retreat from its ambition against Iran and national interests,” said Khamenei, also quoted by the Spanish agency EFE. The country's highest political and religious authority has assured that the demonstration of “national power” through unity will lead to “the discouragement of the enemy”. Khamenei warned that, as long as the enemy is not discouraged, “he will not stop causing inconvenience” to the Iranians. He also mentioned that on February 11, 1979, the Iranian people achieved a “great victory by freeing the country from foreign intervention”. Khamenei did not participate on Sunday in the annual meeting with the commanders of the Air Force, the first military body to join the 1979 revolution. Blood in the streets The speech comes at one of the Islamic Republic's most fragile moments, after the violent repression of protests against the regime and in the face of the threat of US military intervention if a nuclear agreement is not reached. The demonstrations, which began on December 28th due to the devaluation of the currency in Tehran, spread throughout the country and were crushed on January 8th and 9th. The Iranian government admitted the deaths of 3,117 people, attributing the violence to the United States and Israel. The non-governmental organization HRANA, based in North American territory, counted 6,961 deaths, and is still verifying more than 11 thousand possible deaths and 51 thousand arrests. The UN special rapporteur for Iran, Mai Sato, said that medical reports point to the possibility of up to 20,000 deaths, although the United Nations highlights the difficulty of corroborating the data. Following the crackdown, authorities launched a wave of arrests of moderate political figures and activists. At the same time, Iran and the United States resumed negotiations for a nuclear agreement last week, in the first meeting after the 12-day war between Tehran and Tel Aviv. The United States participated in the conflict by bombing Iranian nuclear facilities.

item.title: Concerts | Ticket scam embezzles five women
item.description: Five women from the interior of China were allegedly defrauded of more than 18 thousand patacas in a scheme related to concert tickets. According to the Chinese Radio Macau channel, the fraud scheme was similar to all the victims and began with a comment from the alleged fraudster in social media posts made by women who wanted to go to concerts and had difficulty acquiring tickets. One of the victims lost a total of 10,438 patacas, having started by transferring 6,000 patacas as payment for two tickets that the fraudster had arranged. Afterwards, the suspect said that the tickets were already sold out, promising a refund that never happened. The scammer also sent QR codes for victims to contact a fake employee from a financial department who would help with reimbursement, leading victims to transfer more money. In this woman's case, another three thousand patacas were transferred, with the suspect claiming that the operation had not been successful, demanding more payments. Só então a mulher percebeu que poderia estar a ser vítima de burla, queixando-se à polícia. The Judicial Police (PJ) says it received complaints regarding five cases of fraud between the 6th and 8th of February, all of which are being investigated. Ainda não houve detenções.

item.title: Book by Rui Leão and Carlotta Bruni launched in Lisbon this week
item.description: This Friday, the 13th, in Lisbon, the launch of the book by local architects Rui Leão and Carlotta Bruni, “Layering The City”, will take place at the Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation. The session starts at 11:30 am and is part of the third International Congress on Colonial and Post-Colonial Landscapes, Architecture, Cities and Work, with a presentation by the authors themselves. “Layering The City” is an investigation into infrastructures and public spaces in Macau, revealing the perspectives that Rui Leão and Carlotta Bruni put into each project they undertake, with a focus on projects such as social housing in the Fai Chi Kei neighborhood, the Barra station and the Intermodal zone, related to the Light Rail. As explained by Rui Leão in an interview with HM, the book is composed “of texts by some critics about our work”, namely Jorge Figueira, and an interview conducted by academic Ana Vaz Milheiro, also author of the preface. In this book, there is the idea of ​​construction in layers, revealing the different perspectives of the two architects in each project they carry out. "There is work brought by each person to the project, which involves responding to the programmed request, what the client asks for, what lives in the alignment plan [of the project], or a series of issues at a civic level, public space or the right to quality of life. There are a series of social dimensions [to take into account to] make spaces for people, even when they are impossible [in terms] of politics and in the city. It is these layers that enter the projects and that, deep down, pass for creating opportunities to improve the life of the city, the person, the street”, said Rui Leão in the same interview. Portuguese houses Meanwhile, architect Rui Leão also participates, as co-curator, in the exhibition “Habitar Portugal 1974-2924″, opened this Wednesday, starting at 7pm, at the Architecture Center – Garagem Sul, at the Centro Cultural de Belém, in Lisbon. This is an initiative that marks 50 years of Democracy through a selection of one hundred works of Portuguese Architecture, built in Portugal and around the world between 1974 and 2024”, with the team of curators Alexandra Saraiva and Célia Gomes. According to the official description of the exhibition, available on the CCB website, what is sought is to look at architecture “as a political gesture; to highlight positions of rupture; to enhance the persistence of memories”. You can see projects such as the Hotel Dom Henrique, in Porto, designed by José Carlos Loureiro, or the Complexo das Amoreiras, by Tomás Taveira. Highlights include works such as the Côa Museum, by Camilo Rebelo and Tiago Pimentel, or the requalification project of Casa do Passal – Museu Aristides de Sousa Mendes, by the studio Rosmaninho + Azevedo. This is the seventh edition of the “Habitar Portugal” exhibition, with one hundred works having been chosen “with different programs and different scales, guided by national and international representation (including the Portuguese expression built outside the country)”. According to the same note, “this is a significant and valuable record that not only offers a panoramic look at the last quarter of the 20th century and the first of the 21st century, but also seeks to project the future of contemporary Portuguese architecture, and consequently the social, economic and territorial development of Portugal in the world”.

item.title: HK | Beijing defends “severe punishment” for Jimmy Lai
item.description: The heavy sentence imposed on the former press tycoon received applause from Beijing for concluding that Jimmy Lai seriously endangered national security The Chinese government yesterday defended that businessman and activist Jimmy Lai deserves a “severe punishment” for having “severely endangered” national security, following his sentence to 20 years in prison in Hong Kong. At a press conference, Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Lin Jian stated that Lai “was one of the main organizers and participants in a series of anti-China incidents that destabilized Hong Kong”, in a reference to the 2019 anti-government demonstrations. According to Lin, the actions of the founder of the Apple Daily newspaper, which has since closed, “severely harmed the prosperity, stability and well-being of Hong Kong”. The central government “firmly supports” the authorities of the Special Administrative Region “in safeguarding national security, in accordance with the law, and in punishing crimes that put it at risk”, he added. In response to international criticism of the sentence, Lin Jian urged “to respect China's sovereignty and the rule of law in Hong Kong”, asking that “irresponsible statements be avoided” and “stop interfering in Hong Kong's judicial affairs and China's internal affairs”. Criticisms and appeals The human rights organization Chinese Human Rights Defenders (CHRD) reacted to the decision, classifying the conviction as “political” and highlighting that Jimmy Lai, aged 78, was the target of a long judicial process, having been found guilty in December 2025. The CHRD recalled that United Nations experts in 2024 considered Lai's detention as “arbitrary” and called for his release on humanitarian grounds after the December verdict. The trial took place before three judges designated specifically for cases related to the National Security Law. The indictment attributed to the businessman a sustained campaign to promote international sanctions against China and Hong Kong, through Apple Daily and his network of contacts. The defense argued that the published content was part of the public debate protected by the right to freedom of expression. EU condemns sentence The European Union (EU) yesterday condemned the 20-year prison sentence imposed on Jimmy Lai, a businessman linked to the media, by a Hong Kong court and demanded his immediate release. “The EU deplores the harsh 20-year prison sentence imposed on British citizen and media businessman Jimmy Lai by the Hong Kong High Court on 9 February 2026”, reads the statement published by the European Union External Action Service. According to the diplomatic service of the European bloc, “the EU reiterates its call for the immediate and unconditional release of Jimmy Lai, also taking into account his advanced age and health”. “The political persecution of Jimmy Lai and former Apple Daily executives and journalists damages Hong Kong’s reputation,” the statement highlighted. “Deserved” penalty Hong Kong Chief Executive John Lee said yesterday that the founder of the Apple Daily newspaper, Jimmy Lai, “deserved” the 20-year prison sentence imposed on him. Lai was convicted of three counts of conspiracy to collude with foreign forces and publishing seditious material. Eight other defendants in the same case received sentences ranging from six years and three months to ten years in prison. In a statement, John Lee stated that the 156 days of public hearings “with a large volume of evidence presented” proved that Jimmy Lai was “a despicable and unscrupulous anti-China leader”. “The defendant committed several heinous crimes and his malicious acts are beyond measure,” the official added. For Lee, the heavy sentence “demonstrates that the rule of law is respected and that justice was served”, which “brings relief to everyone”. The Chief Executive admitted, however, that Hong Kong “has already paid a heavy price”, stating that many residents, especially young people, were “misled” by Apple Daily during the 2019 protests, becoming “radical”.

item.title: Research | Businessman Ng Lap Seng in the Epstein files
item.description: Local businessman Ng Lap Seng, convicted in the Public Works case, appears in five Epstein files due to the trial in New York in which he was sentenced to three years in prison. References appear in newsletters analyzing investigation trends into “white collar” crimes and in email exchanges between FBI departments Macau businessman Ng Lap Seng, who was released from Coloane prison last year after serving two and a half years in the Public Works case, also appears in the Epstein files, analyzed by HM. It is recalled that Ng Lap Seng was sentenced in 2018 in the United States to three years in prison for bribing the president of the United Nations General Assembly, John Ashe, to guarantee support for the construction of an international organization's conference center in Macau. In an email sent by a firm of legal analysts, with the receiver crossed out, in which a compilation of news and analyzes of cases of financial corruption is made, there is news about the Ng Lap Seng case and how an accomplice of the businessman, in charge of delivering the bribe, escaped a prison sentence for having collaborated with justice. The other reference to Ng Lap Seng appears in an email sent by the Department of Justice itself, about a week before Jeffrey Epstein's death, with a newsletter on investigation trends in international corruption cases. The Macau businessman is mentioned in an article where he says he paid a security firm, made up in part of former FBI agents, to take care of his security in an apartment in New York (mid-town), while he awaited the start of the trial. The other three documents in which Ng Lap Seng's name appears are email exchanges between FBI departments, dated between the end of May and the beginning of June 2019, about two months before Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in a cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York. The subject of the emails indicated is the management of documents discovered in the investigation. At the end of the emails, the cases handled by the Public Prosecutor's Office of the Southern District of New York, in collaboration with the FBI, are listed, including the case of Ng Lap Seng. Life is a party Another lurid detail where references to Macau appear in the “Epstein Library”, as the US Department of Justice calls it”, is in the case that Hanna Bouveng filed against the owner of the New York Global Group, tycoon Benjamin Wey, in a process that culminated in 2015 with compensation of 18 million dollars, which would later be reduced to 5.6 million dollars. The Tianjin-born businessman was accused of defamation in one of the many legal cases he faced. Benjamin Wey's judicial “career” includes accusations of eight crimes of conspiracy, financial and electronic fraud and money laundering, on suspicion of using offshore accounts to hide transactions between Chinese companies and American shell companies. The case would eventually collapse due to illegally obtaining evidence. The reasons why the Epstein files contain documents from the court case between Hanna Bouveng and Benjamin Wey are unclear, something that recurs in the documentary “library”, where a lack of context is the norm. However, the case alleges that two defendants, including Wey, published an article in a magazine with the title: “Do you want to attract Swedish women?”. Hanna Bouveng, of Swedish nationality, is characterized in the article as “a girl who likes to party and who has just arrived at the clubs of New York after a year of providing ‘entertainment’ in clubs in Hong Kong and casinos in Macau”, alluding to prostitution activities.

item.title: Economy | Requests concrete measures to promote NAPE
item.description: With small and medium-sized companies dealing with the reality of the closure of satellite casinos, the deputy linked to the Jiangme community, Lee Koi Ian, asks the Executive for a plan with concrete measures to promote the economy in NAPE With NAPE facing the end of satellite casinos and their impact on the local economy, MP Lee Koi Ian is calling on the Government to come up with measures to deal with the new problems. The position was taken through a written interpellation, published on the Legislative Assembly portal. “As the satellite casinos gradually ceased operations in NAPE, the surrounding commercial districts face a sharp decline in the number of visitors, plunging the entire area into a difficult situation, characterized by imbalance between sectors and the loss of customers”, begins by outlining the scenario, the deputy supported by the Jiangmen community. Lee Koi Ian also recognizes that the Government Action Lines for this year promise to promote “a series of carnival-style events” at NAPE, with experiences that are expected to attract greater “cultural and tourist consumption” in order to “revitalize the image of the community and increase the vitality of the commercial area”. However, the legislator is now asking the Executive for more concrete plans. "Given the value of the location and the commercial base of NAPE's surrounding districts, it is crucial to establish a long-term revitalization mechanism. This is the central approach to avoid dependence on short-term policies, break the impasse of homogenized competition and cultivate a sustainable commercial ecosystem," he said. “Does the Government have a specialized plan to revitalize the commercial areas around NAPE?”, he asks. Profound changes Lee Koi Ian also warns of the difficulties of not only attracting tourists to that area of ​​the city, but making them want to stay and consume there, taking into account the existence of other more attractive places. “The transition of commercial zones from a transit destination to a consumption destination is not only central to sustainable development. It is also a crucial measure to create a local commercial ecosystem”, argues Lee Koi Ian. “In this context, what specific measures will the Government introduce in ZAPE commercial areas, to help small and medium-sized companies to modernize, while cultivating different business formats?”, he asks. The deputy also calls for optimizing NAPE's infrastructure, expanding pedestrian facilities and organizing “various events to increase the circulation of people and stimulate the vitality of local consumption”. The request is made despite the measures being seen only as palliative care to facilitate the transition.

item.title: Food safety | Requests for improvements in supervision
item.description: The assemblyman linked to the Fujian community is concerned about the transport of food in the case of food platforms and also the most recent recalls of baby products Following cases of baby products being withdrawn from the market and reports of food poisoning in local luxury restaurants, MP Chan Lai Kei wants the Government to strengthen food supervision. The request is contained in a written interpellation, released yesterday. According to the deputy linked to the Fujian community, although the Institute for Municipal Affairs (IAM) announced that last year the general approval rate for inspections carried out through food sampling was 99 percent, food safety faces more and new challenges. In relation to baby products, taking into account the recent cases of food recalls, such as powdered milk, the deputy wants to know whether the authorities will be more demanding in providing information on the origin and route of the items. “Neighboring regions have already established a ‘baby food tracking labeling system,’ requiring importers to provide full information about the production chain so that parents can check the food’s journey via a QR code,” Chan wrote. “Will the IAM move forward with the establishment of a ‘special supervision plan for children’s foods’, implementing more frequent tests for powdered milk and children’s complementary foods, as well as regularly publishing the safety levels of brands?”, he asked. Dangers of take-away Other challenges arise associated with the progressive increase in the number of visitors and a new culture of take-away not only for food, but also for drinks. According to Chan, the number of orders on take-away platforms continues to rise every year. However, during transport and waiting times, the deputy indicates that there is no temperature control or hygiene regulations, due to “regulatory gaps”. This is an aspect that the deputy hopes to see changed: “How will the authorities reinforce interdepartmental cooperation, and formulate mandatory standards for the hygiene of take-away boxes, time limits for delivery and separation of packaging when transporting hot and cold food […]?” question. Chan Lai Kei also suggests using digital methods to remotely control food, with random inspections. In the document, the legislator also points out that Macau welcomes more than 40 million visitors annually, and that banquets and festivals are frequent, which increases food risks. For this reason, Chan Lai Kei suggests that the Government draw up a food safety response plan during the peak tourism season so that it can quickly trace the origin of any poisoning.

item.title: Presidential | Seguro wins elections in Macau and nationally
item.description: The former leader of the Socialist Party will be the future President of the Republic of Portugal, succeeding Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa. When 20 parishes still needed to be counted, where the elections were postponed due to bad weather, Seguro collected 66.82 percent of the votes António José Seguro was the winner of the elections and will be the future President of the Republic of Portugal, after having achieved 66.82 percent of the votes (3.4 million votes), against André Ventura's 33.18 percent (1.7 million votes). The candidate linked to the Socialist Party also won in Macau, where he obtained 68.53 percent of the votes, against 31.47 percent for the candidate supported by Chega. In relation to the territory, a total of 1,403 voters were counted, with Seguro collecting 934 votes and Ventura 429 votes. There were also 32 blank votes (2.28 percent) and eight invalid votes (0.57 percent). The results show that there were 971 fewer people voting in the second round in Macau than in the first, when 2,374 votes had been recorded. The abstention rate for the second round among the 57,748 voters reached 97.45 percent, with those voting at 2.43 percent. In the first round, Luís Marques Mendes, a candidate supported by the Social Democratic Party, received the most votes and received 1,073 votes, a figure above that which now contributed to guaranteeing the presidency to António José Seguro. In the first vote, the participation rate was 4.11 percent, which represented an abstention of 95.98 percent. In this round of voting, António José Seguro came in second place, with 477 votes and André Ventura in third, with 282 votes. China was safe Yesterday's results were provisional, as there were still 20 parishes to be counted in Portugal and seven “consulates” abroad. Among the so-called “consulates” by the National Elections Commission, the results from Beijing remained to be determined. However, the votes from Macau combined with those from Shanghai gave Seguro victory, with 944 votes, against Ventura's 432. In Shanghai, Seguro obtained 10 votes, against three for Ventura, with no blank or invalid votes being recorded. Despite the results in China, Ventura managed to be the most voted abroad with 51.88 percent of the votes (42,265) against 48.12 percent for Seguro (39,208), while blank votes were 1.21 percent and invalid votes were 0.65 percent. “Working for Portugal” In his victory speech, António José Seguro promised to work to develop the country and presented himself as the “president of all Portuguese”, even those who did not vote for him. “As the future President of the Republic, I add that from tonight onwards we are no longer adversaries and we now have a shared duty to work for a more developed and fairer Portugal”, stated the winner of the night, in a speech given in Caldas da Rainha. “The majority that elected me disappears tonight [Sunday]”, he added. 2nd round of presidential elections in Macau Candidate Percentage of Votes Total Votes António José Seguro 68.53% 934 votes André Ventura 31.47% 429 votes Voters 2.43% Abstention 97.57% 1,403 voters 57,748 subscribers

item.title: Cooperation | Relations between China and Timor-Leste guided by caution, study indicates
item.description: It is certain that, by being part of the “One Belt, One Road” initiative, Timor-Leste can become a strategic point in commercial relations on this side of the globe, despite the “cautious pragmatism” in relations with China. The conclusion is a study on Timorese foreign policy within the scope of the Chinese initiative, authored by three Portuguese academics Timor-Leste, a young country, has been cementing its relations with China, namely through the “One Belt, One Road” initiative, but there is still some caution surrounding this relationship. This is one of the conclusions of the study “Timor-Leste's foreign policy options within the scope of China's Belt and Road 2.0 Initiative: a small state perspective”, authored by academics Tiago Botelho dos Santos, Diogo Borges and Paulo Afonso Duarte. The work was published in The Pacific Review, an academic journal edited by Taylor & Francis. The research work starts with Timor-Leste's adherence to the Chinese initiative, something that happened in 2017, to analyze how the relationship with China has been going, taking into account the fact that Timor-Leste has “the status of a small state”. It is concluded, therefore, that “Timor-Leste's involvement with China's Belt and Road Initiative, particularly in the post-2023 period, can be understood as a strategic and calculated attempt to maximize its status as a small state in a complex regional and global environment”. It is described that, in this period, Timorese foreign policy has been characterized “by a multi-vector approach, strategically anchored in multilateralism”, seeking to “diversify international partnerships to reinforce national security, promote economic development and expand its voice in the international system”. The study points out that relations between Timor-Leste and China, in the context of the Belt and Road initiative, are a “deliberate movement to leverage development opportunities” in the country, being a strategy aligned with the Timor-Leste Strategic Development Plan 2011-2030. The plan aims to “promote economic diversification and the development of critical infrastructure, in a context in which the Belt and Road 2.0 Initiative emphasizes digital infrastructure, green energy and cooperation in the area of ​​health”. Timorese potential The three academics also highlight that Timor-Leste, as part of the Chinese geopolitical initiative, has the potential to stand out economically, and also in commercial terms, in the region. The country has “the potential to assert itself as a logistical center on a route that connects the South Indian Ocean to the South Pacific”, so the Chinese initiative “offers a relevant opportunity to significantly increase its regional prominence and decisively facilitate” integration into ASEAN [Association of Southeast Asian Nations], to which Timor-Leste recently joined. Despite all these positive signs, the study concludes that “although Timor-Leste's relationship with China has deepened, culminating in a comprehensive strategic partnership in 2024, its engagement continues to be marked by cautious pragmatism”. In this context, “the benefits of greater connectivity and investment are carefully weighed against concerns regarding debt sustainability, transparency and possible strategic dependencies”. This caution on the part of Timor-Leste demonstrates its “capacity for action by selectively engaging in projects aligned with its national interests”, navigating the “complexities of competition between great powers in the Indo-Pacific, while maintaining its commitment to a balanced and diversified foreign policy”. Timorese pragmatism is also evident, according to the study, in the fact that the country “not only optimizes development opportunities, but also reinforces its regional position by meticulously analyzing economic benefits in the face of potential risks”. What is strengthened, “ultimately”, is the “capacity for action as a small State”, highlight the authors. A “remarkable” ability The study in question highlights how Timor-Leste has had “a remarkable capacity for action” in the context of the “One Belt, One Road” initiative, using other small States, such as Sri Lanka, as a point of comparison. Citing other studies, the three academics highlight how “Timor-Leste has demonstrated a more cautious approach than countries like Sri Lanka, which have faced significant concerns about debt sustainability associated with BRI [Belt and Road Initiative] projects, or landlocked states like Laos and coastal nations like Cambodia.” In the case of these Southeast Asian countries, “Chinese loans for emblematic projects, such as railways and highways, have drastically increased external debt and dependence on Beijing”. What we sought to do in this investigation was “to examine the unique position of Timor-Leste, not as a financier, but also not as a victim of a ‘debt trap'”, highlighting “the distinct and valuable form of action capacity of a small State within the scope of the BRI”. The authors highlight that, in the last decade, China “significantly expanded its presence in Southeast Asia” through the “One Belt, One Road” initiative, thereby “expanding its regional influence in the economic, security and political spheres”. In this relationship, Timor-Leste has been “far from being a passive observer”, seeking to “actively engage with China to ensure development benefits”. Timor-Leste sought to “identify an opportunity to align with the long-term objectives” of its Strategic Development Plan 2011-2030, analysts indicate. “Strategically, the country also intends to capitalize on its geographic position in emerging commercial maritime routes, particularly through the establishment of a logistics hub in the South Indian Ocean and the South Pacific, potentially reinforcing its regional role as a new integrated member state of ASEAN”, point out the authors. Timor-Leste seeks to “balance economic gains and potential dependencies”, in a geopolitical context that “includes competition between great powers in the Indo-Pacific, where United States policies, under successive administrations, aim to contain China's regional influence”. In methodological terms, the authors carried out this investigation based on reading official reports, documents that serve as the basis for signed bilateral agreements and government documentation. In addition, interviews were carried out with “experts based in both Europe and Asia”. The authors state that they sought to interview academics and diplomats “due to the fact that ordinary citizens are generally unfamiliar with China's global multilateral initiatives, while diplomats tend to be excessively cautious in their statements, as they represent the official position of their state, and not necessarily their personal opinions”. It is therefore understood that academics “tend to offer more balanced and rigorous analyses”. The questions focused on how Timor-Leste, as a small State, has benefited from the Chinese initiative, whether this initiative is compatible with the Timor-Leste Strategic Development Plan 2011-2030, or whether “there are visible dangers of creating dependency” between the two countries, among other issues.

The Judicial Police (PJ) says it received complaints regarding five cases of fraud between the 6th and 8th of February, all of which are being investigated. There have been no arrests yet.

item.title: Book by Rui Leão and Carlotta Bruni launched in Lisbon this week
item.description: This Friday, the 13th, in Lisbon, the launch of the book by local architects Rui Leão and Carlotta Bruni, “Layering The City”, will take place at the Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation. The session starts at 11:30 am and is part of the third International Congress on Colonial and Post-Colonial Landscapes, Architecture, Cities and Work, with a presentation by the authors themselves. “Layering The City” is an investigation into infrastructures and public spaces in Macau, revealing the perspectives that Rui Leão and Carlotta Bruni put into each project they undertake, with a focus on projects such as social housing in the Fai Chi Kei neighborhood, the Barra station and the Intermodal zone, related to the Light Rail. As explained by Rui Leão in an interview with HM, the book is composed “of texts by some critics about our work”, namely Jorge Figueira, and an interview conducted by academic Ana Vaz Milheiro, also author of the preface. In this book, there is the idea of ​​construction in layers, revealing the different perspectives of the two architects in each project they carry out. "There is work brought by each person to the project, which involves responding to the programmed request, what the client asks for, what lives in the alignment plan [of the project], or a series of issues at a civic level, public space or the right to quality of life. There are a series of social dimensions [to take into account to] make spaces for people, even when they are impossible [in terms] of politics and in the city. It is these layers that enter the projects and that, deep down, pass for creating opportunities to improve the life of the city, the person, the street”, said Rui Leão in the same interview. Portuguese houses Meanwhile, architect Rui Leão also participates, as co-curator, in the exhibition “Habitar Portugal 1974-2924″, opened this Wednesday, starting at 7pm, at the Architecture Center – Garagem Sul, at the Centro Cultural de Belém, in Lisbon. This is an initiative that marks 50 years of Democracy through a selection of one hundred works of Portuguese Architecture, built in Portugal and around the world between 1974 and 2024”, with the team of curators Alexandra Saraiva and Célia Gomes. According to the official description of the exhibition, available on the CCB website, what is sought is to look at architecture “as a political gesture; to highlight positions of rupture; to enhance the persistence of memories”. You can see projects such as the Hotel Dom Henrique, in Porto, designed by José Carlos Loureiro, or the Complexo das Amoreiras, by Tomás Taveira. Highlights include works such as the Côa Museum, by Camilo Rebelo and Tiago Pimentel, or the requalification project of Casa do Passal – Museu Aristides de Sousa Mendes, by the studio Rosmaninho + Azevedo. This is the seventh edition of the “Habitar Portugal” exhibition, with one hundred works having been chosen “with different programs and different scales, guided by national and international representation (including the Portuguese expression built outside the country)”. According to the same note, “this is a significant and valuable record that not only offers a panoramic look at the last quarter of the 20th century and the first of the 21st century, but also seeks to project the future of contemporary Portuguese architecture, and consequently the social, economic and territorial development of Portugal in the world”.

item.title: Concert | South Korean group Treasure in Macau next month
item.description: The Venetian Arena is preparing to host, on March 6th, another K-Pop concert, this time by the boy band Treasure. The group from South Korea, made up of ten members, was created in 2019 and was born in the context of a television program made to discover musical talents The band Treasure, from South Korea, has only been alive for a few years, but their success seems to be guaranteed. Proof of this is the group's show that Macau will host on March 6th at the Venetian Arena, in Cotai, from 8pm, as part of the “Treasure Tour [Pulse On] in Macao”. Treasure are a boy band formed in 2019 through the YG Treasure Box talent hunt program, which aimed to train this group of young singers. Of the more than 20 candidates, who had to pass several challenging tests to demonstrate their talent, the ten best voices were chosen. Currently, the group consists of Choi Hyun-suk, Jihoon, Yoshi, Junkyu, Yoon Jae-hyuk, Asahi, Doyoung, Haruto, Park Jeong-woo and So Jung-hwan. The recipe of combining the creation of a group of singing boys with a television program seems to have worked, and the truth is that success was felt as soon as they started composing songs and publishing them on the market. In August 2020, “BOY”, the first single, was released, and “The First Step: Chapter One” was also released that year. This record work was part of a trilogy of albums that, as a whole, sold more than a million copies in just five months. According to the description of the show in Macau, available on the Venetian Arena website, it is said that the concert reveals how Treasure are “expanding their global influence”, as the first tour, just in Japan in 2023, included eight cities and 26 shows. At that time, the tour attracted “almost 300,000 spectators and set the record for the highest audience for a debut tour by a Korean artist”. The first tour in Asia followed, this time with 17 cities included and a total of 40 concerts. In 2024, Japan once again hosted a Treasure tour, which included two meetings with fans, while last year the “Treasure Fan Concert [Special Moment] took place. These moments were also revealing of the group's success, as together they “surpassed an accumulated audience of one million [people], demonstrating their status and the band's power in live performances”. On the road since 2025 Treasure come to Macau with new songs under their belt. The third mini-album, titled “Love Pulse”, was released on September 1st, and in March it was time for the record market to receive “Pleasure”, a “special mini-album”. The concert at the Venetian Arena is part of the group's tour that has marked Treasure's schedule since the second half of 2025. In October, the group gave three consecutive concerts in Seoul, and then performed again in Japan.

item.title: Nuclear | Largest nuclear power plant in the world reactivated
item.description: The Japanese electricity company TEPCO (Tokyo Electric Power Company) yesterday reactivated the Kashiwazaki-Kariwa (KK) nuclear power plant, the largest in the world in terms of capacity and closed in 2011 after the accident in Fukushima. “At 14:00, the control bars were removed and reactor number 6 of the nuclear plant was put into operation,” TEPCO said in a statement. The restart of the reactor had been suspended last January after an alarm was raised. The company added that it will continue to check “the integrity of the plant's equipment” and stated that it will respond “sincerely” to inspections by the Nuclear Regulatory Authority. The company plans to gradually increase the amount of power generated at Kashiwazaki-Kariwa until it resumes commercial operations from March 18. With a capacity of more than 8,000 megawatts (MW), the Kashiwazaki-Kariwa plant is a fundamental piece in TEPCO's energy supply plan and is in line with the strategy promoted by the Japanese Government of Sanae Takaichi to boost nuclear plants and meet emissions reduction targets.

item.title: Tourism | Associations want activities in neighborhoods to attract visitors
item.description: The president of the Macau Tourist Industry Association, Andy Wu, thinks that the Government can improve plans to attract tourists to residential neighborhoods, which are on the margins in terms of commerce for the many visitors who arrive in Macau. Speaking to the newspaper Ou Mun, the businessman also argued that although last year the Government launched several activities in residential neighborhoods, the short duration of the initiatives did not allow them to create lasting impressions among tourists. Without asking for a daily schedule in these areas of the city, Andy Wu would like to see regular activities every weekend, in order to put places that are not normally visited “on the map” for tourists. Furthermore, the person responsible understands that transport to community neighborhoods must be improved to facilitate access for tourists. With the Chinese New Year holidays next week, travel agency entrepreneur Paul Wong also indicated that the Government should continue to close areas of the city to traffic to divert visitors from the most popular tourist attractions.

item.title: Today Macau
item.description: Iran's supreme leader yesterday called on Iranians to use the 47th anniversary of the Islamic Revolution on Wednesday to demonstrate strength against the enemy, in a context of tensions with the United States. Since 1979, “foreign powers have always sought to reestablish the previous situation”, declared Ali Khamenei, in reference to external influence during the Pahlavi dynasty (1925-1979), an ally of the Americans, which was removed from power by the revolution. Led by the then 'ayatollah' Ruhollah Khomeini, Shiite fundamentalists established the Islamic Republic following the 1979 revolution, which deposed Mohammad Reza Pahlavi, the last shah of Iran, formally called Persia until 1935. “The power of a nation lies not so much in its missiles and planes, but in the will and resilience of its people,” said Khamenei, quoted by the France-Presse news agency (AFP). “Show it again and thwart the enemy’s plans,” said the supreme leader, calling on Iranians to participate in the anniversary of the revolution. “The presence of the people at the march and the expression of loyalty to the Islamic Republic will make the enemy retreat from its ambition against Iran and national interests,” said Khamenei, also quoted by the Spanish agency EFE. The country's highest political and religious authority has assured that the demonstration of “national power” through unity will lead to “the discouragement of the enemy”. Khamenei warned that, as long as the enemy is not discouraged, “he will not stop causing inconvenience” to the Iranians. He also mentioned that on February 11, 1979, the Iranian people achieved a “great victory by freeing the country from foreign intervention”. Khamenei did not participate on Sunday in the annual meeting with the commanders of the Air Force, the first military body to join the 1979 revolution. Blood in the streets The speech comes at one of the Islamic Republic's most fragile moments, after the violent repression of protests against the regime and in the face of the threat of US military intervention if a nuclear agreement is not reached. The demonstrations, which began on December 28th due to the devaluation of the currency in Tehran, spread throughout the country and were crushed on January 8th and 9th. The Iranian government admitted the deaths of 3,117 people, attributing the violence to the United States and Israel. The non-governmental organization HRANA, based in North American territory, counted 6,961 deaths, and is still verifying more than 11 thousand possible deaths and 51 thousand arrests. The UN special rapporteur for Iran, Mai Sato, said that medical reports point to the possibility of up to 20,000 deaths, although the United Nations highlights the difficulty of corroborating the data. Following the crackdown, authorities launched a wave of arrests of moderate political figures and activists. At the same time, Iran and the United States resumed negotiations for a nuclear agreement last week, in the first meeting after the 12-day war between Tehran and Tel Aviv. The United States participated in the conflict by bombing Iranian nuclear facilities.

item.title: Paulo Maia and Carmo
item.description: Jiang Shinian, also known as Shennong, the «Divine Farmer», patron saint of practitioners of traditional medicine (zhongyi), is also known as Yandi, the «emperor of flames» and is therefore able to control the «flaming wind», the excess heat that causes symptoms such as tremors, confusion or sudden fever. In religious practice, this “fire in the wind” is understood as the smoke that results from the burning of incense or papers that carry prayers, offerings or messages to the gods, ancestors or spirits up to the heavens. This fire, represented by the color red, is associated, among others, with immortality, positive energy forces or protection against evil. Shades of the color red were notoriously adopted by the emperors of the Ming dynasty who had Zhu, “vermilion or cinnabar” as their family name. One of the most publicly manifest examples was painting the walls of the “Forbidden Imperial City”, Zijincheng, purple, as a form of protection for the occupants inside, or giving the clothing of literate officials the color of cinnabar. When the dynasty fell and for many literati it became intolerable to obey the new emperors, some adopted the most diverse and subtle strategies of resistance. A scholar from the North who, in the plurality of his knowledge and vocations, came to use more than thirty names of brush, created for himself the name Zhuyi daoren, the «Daoist dressed in cinnabar» as if by using this protective color, he only recognized his own body as the only border or wall. In ordinary life, his name was Fu Shan (1607-1684), born in Yangqu, Shanxi, and from his refusal to serve his new masters, which harmed his day-to-day life, countless talents emerged, still celebrated today in two gardens in the city of Taiyuan, the provincial capital. And although all the literati who knew him recognized his qualities as a calligrapher, painter or poet, those closest to him saw him as a practitioner of traditional medicine, in particular as an expert on women's illnesses. Fu Shan preferred his handwriting to be “rough, not skillful; ugly, not seductive; deformed, not thin; spontaneous, not premeditated». And just like in paintings, he liked long vertical formats, as can be seen in a couplet in the Smithonian (ink on paper, 226 x 45.5 cm) where, reflecting his dual concern with the spirit and the body, he wrote: «If the spirit is calm, the mind naturally reaches the distance; The more relaxed your body is, the more of life you will be able to enjoy». He is credited with creating an “eight treasure soup”, made with eight ingredients that restored the most weakened. And yet, when he was forced to go to court in Beijing for the ritual of obedience to the new dynasty, he threw himself to the ground, suffering an incapacitating illness. Walking along the riverbank, enjoying the flowers, 6 (out of 7): Access to Huangsi's in-laws' house it is full of flowers everywhere, There are a thousand, ten thousand flowers pressing the branches, so full, bent. Repeatedly invite the butterflies to stay constantly dancing, I listen to orioles: how they are tuned in your delicate chirp. Du Fu (712-770)

item.title: USJ | Book highlights panorama of philanthropy in Macau
item.description: The book “Media, Art & Technology in the Nine Portuguese Speaking Cultures” has just been published by the University of São José. One of the chapters deals with philanthropy in Macau, the discreet profile of philanthropists and the work of entities such as Fundação Rui Cunha, Banco Nacional Ultramarino and Fundação Oriente The University of São José (USJ) has just published the book “Media, Art & Technology in the Nine Portuguese Speaking Cultures”, edited by professor José Manuel Simões. As the name indicates, the work aims to outline the panorama of arts, media and culture in the nine Portuguese-speaking countries and regions, which includes Macau. Macao SAR is represented with a chapter dedicated to philanthropy, written by Carmen Zita Monereo, post-doctoral student at USJ, entitled “The Impact of Corporate Philanthropy on Media, Art, and Technology in Macao / What do we know about Philanthropy in Macao? What is the relationship between Confucianism, Philanthropy, Media, and strategic communication?”. “Carmen has been developing a study on philanthropy in Macau, which is a slightly different work than the rest”, she began by telling HM José Manuel Simões. "This is a work that contributes to the analysis of the spectrum of philanthropists in Macau, then outlining a study on the Rui Cunha Foundation, Banco Nacional Ultramarino, Fundação Oriente. It looks at what corporate philanthropy is and the impacts it has on society through an analysis of the media, but also art and technology in Macau. In other words, it questions what we know about philanthropy in Macau and what is the relationship between Confucianism, philanthropy, the media and strategic communication.” José Manuel Simões adds that one of the innovative points in this chapter is the discreet profile of philanthropists. “A curious aspect is that, unlike philanthropists from Europe and the United States, who really like to appear in rankings, in Macau there is greater discretion and a low profile of these people linked to philanthropy, and this has to do with the culture itself.” The editor of the work adds that “in the field of communication sciences [in Macau] philanthropy has gained great importance as a communication instrument”, and that Carmen Zita Monereo’s work “identifies the values ​​of an organizational culture that is capable of generating communication flows conducive to innovation through this philanthropic activity”. The book, which is available for free in digital version, “seeks to draw links between various vectors, and one of them is the nine Portuguese-speaking cultures”, without forgetting Macau “as a connection platform between China and Portuguese-speaking countries”. According to José Manuel Simões, it is a book “whose research was developed seeking to adopt a multidisciplinary approach”, having “an academic nature, but, at the same time, it aims to have a simple and accessible language”. Cape Verde’s good example With a bilingual edition, the book presents “a very broad spectrum” of themes, containing an article by José Manuel Simões on São Tomé and Príncipe, entitled “Digital Media Contribution to Entrepreneurship and Development in São Tomé and Príncipe”. Below is an article on the educational panorama in Angola and the use of artificial intelligence (AI), written by Wilson Gomes Caldeira, entitled “Angola’s higher education system: An analysis of the opportunities and challenges presented by Artificial Intelligence”. In the case of Cape Verde, Silvino Lopes Évora explores the ideas of social communication in conjunction with AI, in “Artificial Intelligence, newsroom culture, and journalism: From international spectrum to experiences in Cape Verde”. “Cape Verde is a good example of media development in Africa and Silvino Évora's text works on the AI ​​component in the media and how it is being inserted. [The text also analyzes] what are the possibilities for using AI and how ethics can monitor and support AI and, at the same time, journalism”, adds José Manuel Simões. The book published by USJ also explores, in the chapter “The media system as a leverage for democratic development in East Timor”, by Paulo Faustino and Rui Alexandre Novais, the links between journalism and the historical memories of the independence process. The book's editor explains the “more historical component regarding the role of remission that journalists still have today to almost preserve the memory of those who died in favor of the country's independence”. "Journalism is of enormous importance in Timor, there were people and journalists who died. This is very little talked about and in this study there is an interesting conclusion, that these people, when they died in the name of freedom of expression, left a very important place in Timor-Leste that is still in force today, seeking to preserve their memory through surveillance over other powers." In this way, “Timor-Leste is almost an example of how journalism should act as a watchdog of other powers, which does not happen in other sectors”. José Manuel Simões highlights the case of Guinea-Bissau, “where journalists are called hired mouths”. "They don't know the difference between advertising, public relations, marketing and journalism, because they are conditioned by a very low salary. They write what they ask for in exchange for an envelope with some money inside, and this makes the profession [of journalism] very fragile in Guinea Bissau", he stressed. A language of unity According to José Manuel Simões, the book aims to unite “these quadrants of Portuguese cultures”, and the English edition aims to reach Anglo-Saxon communities, “so that they know about the existence of these cultures”. "There are those who do not agree with me regarding the idea that the Portuguese language is a language of unity, not only among Portuguese-speaking peoples, but even within each country. We have the case of Timor-Leste, which on the island of Ataúro alone, which is very small, with 500 thousand inhabitants, has 40 dialects, one in each village. There, what does the Portuguese language do? It unites these people, because despite there being a difference between the who speak and those who learned Portuguese, in Timor-Leste, today, the elderly speak Portuguese and young people too, but there is the age group that goes from 25 to 50, who do not speak it. But, because it is a language of learning, because it is official, because it has books, a memory, Portuguese unites all these ethnicities and dialects, and has a common value, because the Portuguese language is everyone's mother tongue”, he explains. José Manuel Simões does not forget the work that CPLP – Community of Portuguese Speaking Countries, has done in this regard. "The CPLP had a wonderful idea of ​​uniting us through language, but the CPLP has done vague, limited and barely visible work. In fact, very few people have done a worthy job of creating links between new Portuguese-speaking cultures. In this sense, this book fills a gap and brings new data about these new cultures, with this technological and innovative dynamic", this in relation to the QR codes for all chapters of the book. Each code gives access to a video that summarizes the author's work in each chapter. In global terms, “Media, Art & Technology in the Nine Portuguese Speaking Cultures” aims to be comprehensive in areas such as technology, art, culture and social communication. There is, however, “a common denominator, creating, curiously, a certain harmony, even with different focuses, and ends up covering, directly and indirectly, the spectrum of social communication”, he concludes.

item.title: Diocese of Macau/450 years | New Catholic Center will have a hotel
item.description: The new Catholic Center should open “in the middle of the second quarter” of this year and will have a hotel, prepared to receive “pilgrims and tourists”, says the Diocese of Macau. At a time when the institution celebrates 450 years, the inauguration of the Catholic Center is based on “the vision” of D. Paulo José Tavares, bishop of Macau in the 60s and 70s After many years of emptiness and construction work on the corner of Avenida da Praia Grande and Rua do Campo, the new Catholic Center is preparing to open its doors later this year and is perhaps the most important event in the celebration of the 450th anniversary of the Diocese of Macau. HM asked questions to the Diocese of Macau regarding the reopening of the building, which confirmed that the official opening is scheduled “for the second quarter” of this year. This building, with a total of 17 floors, will have features designed for religious purposes, but also a hotel prepared to receive all types of people. "The Catholic Center will be a nerve center for disseminating and sharing the mission of the Catholic Church. The lower floors will feature a chapel, an auditorium, conference rooms, exhibition areas and spaces for activities." While “the upper floors will function as a hotel, offering welcoming and comfortable accommodation, imbued with a spirit of service”. In the diocese's written response, it is added that the hotel facilities “were designed to receive both pilgrims and tourists, welcoming Catholics and non-Catholics with hospitality and inclusion”. It is worth remembering that in December employees began to be recruited for the hotel unit, in partnership with the Directorate of Services for Labor Affairs (DSAL). In a job matching session aimed at residents, held on December 5th, with the “Companhia de Gestão do Centro Católico”, 23 job openings were made available for sales manager, assistant reception manager, chef, head of security, room service supervisor and acquisition supervisor, reads the DSAL note released in November. The Diocese of Macau did not want to tell HM how much it would cost to rebuild the new Catholic Center, saying only that initial forecasts had slipped due to the pandemic. "The Catholic Center is currently undergoing development and submission and approval by the Government. Following the challenges of the Covid-19 pandemic, construction costs have increased significantly. We are grateful for the understanding and support of the builders and contractors, which allowed the reconstruction project to be completed successfully. At the same time, we warmly welcome donations from all sectors of society to help sustain and carry forward the Catholic Center's original mission of serving the Macau community." A bishop still present Asked about the main goals of the new Catholic Center, the Diocese of Macau describes that the building “aims to continue the spiritual mission of the Catholic Church and incorporate the spirit of Christ”, influenced by the work of Bishop D. Paulo José Tavares, who carried out his mission in Macau in the mid-20th century. Of particular note is the fact that D. Paulo José Tavares, who died in 1973 and was appointed Bishop of Macau in 1961, was important in maintaining the presence of the Catholic Church in Macau at the time of the “1,2,3” movement. Between November 1966 and February 1967, the Cultural Revolution manifested itself in the territory, bringing together many local students, who intended to change the content of Catholic education. D. Paulo José Tavares fought with these groups of protesters, managing to keep teaching in Catholic schools and the spirit associated with them unchanged. In this way, and based on “the vision” of this bishop, the diocese intends for the new Catholic Center to “continue to serve as a vital bridge for the Macau community, promoting dialogue, exchange and integration of faith and culture”. It is also the intention to “open the doors [of the Center] to visitors from all over the world, reinforcing not only its role as a spiritual refuge, but also infusing new vitality into the religious and cultural panorama of Macau”. António Pedro Costa, author of the cleric's biography, entitled “D. Paulo José Tavares – The diplomat bishop”, described, in an interview with HM in 2023, that the bishop “was a breath of fresh air”, and a figure cherished by the Chinese community at the time. "These attitudes of valuing the Chinese community led to a rapprochement and the establishment of a relationship of trust. Only in this way was he able to take his objectives forward, as he realized that he had to have the population on his side. But this caused him a lot of trouble with the European clergy, who did not agree with D. Paulo José Tavares' stance. It meant that the population saw him as an ally and not a person who comes from outside and imposes his ideas", said the author. A year of celebrations It was in 1576, in the fourth year of the Wanli reign, of the Ming Dynasty, that the Diocese was founded in Macau, with January 23rd being the official date of celebration. However, the next few months will also be festive. In a previously released statement, the Diocese of Macau states that it has had, over the years, “the mission of establishing bridges between East and West, promoting education, charity and pastoral service”, leaving “a deep and lasting mark on the cultural, educational and religious development of Macau”. The theme of the celebrations is “From Macau to the World: 450 years of Mission and Mercy”. The new Catholic Center will host two thematic exhibitions, entitled “Honoring the Past, Creating the Future” and “Witness to Heritage, Mission in the World”. These exhibitions aim to “reflect the development of the Diocese from historical, personal and cultural perspectives, as well as its future directions”, highlights the same note. Tomorrow a sacred music concert will take place at the Sé Church with eight choral groups from Macau, Hong Kong and the Province of Guangzhou, with the sounds of the church's new pipe organ being heard. From 7:30 pm onwards, the Diocesan Choir of Macau, the Cathedral Schola ensemble and other choral groups from Macau will perform, such as Coro Perosi, Dolce Voce and Cantate Chorus, without forgetting other ensembles from Hong Kong and Guangzhou. The Diocese highlights that the “most symbolic and large-scale initiative of the commemorative year” will be the “great celebration” scheduled for October 31st this year, which consists of a reception and mass. “Through this solemn celebration, the Diocese will give thanks to God for the graces and mission granted over four and a half centuries, and will pray that He continues to guide the way forward”, the same statement describes. There will also be initiatives carried out by “various diocesan institutions” in the coming months, namely “cultural shows, school competitions, academic symposiums, social activities, youth meetings, online training resources, parish initiatives and liturgical celebrations”. “Through transversal and intergenerational participation, the commemorative year seeks to deepen public knowledge about the historical development of the Diocese and its service to the community, promoting the spirit of the diocesan motto ‘Scientia et Virtus’ (Science and Virtue), which inspires a practice of service based on the balance between knowledge and ethical care.” At a time when it celebrates 450 years of existence, the Diocese says it wants to chart the future, “walking with the residents of Macau in reflecting on the past and continuing its mission of faith, service and culture in this new stage”.

item.title: History | Book reveals how Macau was created in the image of Évora
item.description:
The local association Heritage Society has just released a two-volume book on the history of Macau's founding. Authored by Caspar Chan and Nathan Rubene dos Santos, “Foral of the City of the Name of the God, Macau”, contains translations and annotations of documents that show how the founding of Macau had Évora as a model
A book, divided into two volumes, has just been published by the local association Heritage Society, which helps tell the story of the founding of Macau, from the mid-16th century onwards. The two volumes are entitled “Foral of the City of the Name of the God, Macau: Évora of the Far East” and “The Twenty-eight Alvarás”, and are authored by academics Caspar Chan and Nathan Rubene dos Santos. The first volume, which establishes a curious connection between Macau and Évora in the founding of the territory to the East, is based on the archive “Foral, Regalias e Privilégios Concedidos à Cidade de Macau, na China, 1596-1756”, the original of which is kept at the National Archives of Rio de Janeiro, and there are microfilms at the Macau Archive. In turn, the part dedicated to the 28 charters, a continuation of the first volume, analyzes the 28 legal texts initially decreed by the then governor of Macau and viceroy of India, D. Rodrigo da Costa, in 1689. These documents were later confirmed by King D. João V, in Portugal, in 1709. As the authors told HM, in a joint email interview, the first volume “deals with the first part of the archive, or the first 17 sheets, which concern the oldest founding letters, letters and sentences received by the Senate of Macau during the last years of the 16th century”. The second volume analyzes the contents of the file between pages 17 and 33, covering the 28 permits. “This is not yet the complete story, as we intend to continue working on the remaining archive in future years”, confessed the authors. The authors highlight the importance of the charter, an ancient document that consisted of “a charter or contract that the governing power, be it a feudal lord, a bishop or a king, establishes with a local entity, be it a village or city, a senate or a council”. "We consider that the word and the concept are important to reflect on this historical period and not only in Macau, but also the time when the European kingdom [Portugal] was at the height of its expansion across the seas and oceans. The concept of charter implies the way in which a Portuguese social structure was being transplanted and rethought in Macau." In this way, the authors add, all documents analyzed for these two volumes are related to the idea of ​​charter. In turn, the designation “City of the Name of God of Macau” appears, in this specific file, “not only in the charter of King Philip I of Portugal, during the Iberian Union, which stipulates the elevation of Macau from a town to a city, but also throughout the 28 subsequent charters”. In concrete terms, readers can come across “a research work that addresses some of the most important documents in the history of Macau, documents that inform us about the founding of the city and the evolution of its legal and governing tradition”. The connection with Évora The first volume of the work includes the subtitle “Évora of the Far East”, relating “the story in which the town's Senate presented a petition to the Viceroy of India for the recognition of the Senate, for the elevation of this port to the status of city and for the granting to the 'new city' of Macau of the privileges, rights and freedoms of the city of Évora”. D. Duarte de Meneses, at the time governor of Macau and viceroy of India, ended up granting this request on behalf of King D. Filipe I, in 1586, a “decision that was later confirmed by the king himself in 1595”. “To confirm and corroborate that Macau had the same status as Évora, it became natural that all the founding documents of the city of Évora were transcribed to Macau, so that the Senate of Macau could preserve them as evidence and keep them in its archives as founding documents of the city”, explain the authors. The documents found in the archive based in Rio de Janeiro point out that “the ‘proof’ of Macau’s status as a city comparable to Évora does not consist of a single document, but a compilation of several texts”. In the first volume of the work there are examples such as “sentences on the jurisdiction of certain positions, such as the Prosecutor and the Almotacé, royal letters on specific issues, laws on which positions should be part of a Senate, rites of religious and funeral processions and even the configuration of the Senate room”. In short, “everything that Évora possessed de jure during this period was inherited by Macau, as proven by the meticulous transcription and authentication of these documents”, explain the authors. The survival permits Regarding the second volume of the work, focused on the 28 permits, the authors understand that these documents “are particularly significant because they present themselves as a cohesive set, with great integrity in terms of language, format, administration and argumentation”. For Caspar Chan and Nathan Rubene dos Santos, this results from the fact that, at the end of the 17th century, Macau was no longer in its golden period of trade, “due to the loss of commercial routes”. "At the same time, Macau faced constant social unrest, both internally – for example, between the Senate, the Captain-General and the Ouvidor – and externally, in relations with the Chinese and Castilians. The privileges and rights of the Senate were not respected, and it was necessary to resolve ambiguities to guarantee the city's survival, as reflected in the various minutes of the Senate meetings." Thus, a petition was presented by these bodies to governor D. Rodrigo da Costa “for the reaffirmation of the city's rights and to present solutions to various problems, such as the overflow of the jurisdiction of the Captain-General, the preservation of the Padroado in the face of foreign missionary groups and trade with the Chinese and in Solor and Timor”. Thus, the 28 permits emerged, which “also deal with a very diverse group of people from different arts, professions, origins and ideologies”, and not just relations between Portuguese and Chinese, which made “this set of documents particularly interesting to study”. The aim of publishing these two volumes was to facilitate access to the archive and its information. “We intend to place in the hands of Macau readers a fundamental document of the legal and political origin of the city, which remains little studied, even in Portuguese-speaking historiography, and which is almost completely absent from the daily historical imagination of Macau”, they add. The archive based in Rio de Janeiro was translated by the authors “and was never published in full, especially the founding documents related to Évora, not even in Portuguese”. This archive almost always appears “indirectly, as excerpts and paraphrases, such as those of canonical historians of Macau, in the case of Manuel Teixeira; or as references inserted in specialized works, and in some cases only through digitalized transcriptions that circulate in doctoral theses”. In the case of permits, they are “better known among historians, but appear only in very limited publications”. "For this reason, the publication of the primary text itself becomes essential. By presenting it in English and Chinese, alongside Portuguese, we also seek to remove a barrier that has long structured Macau's historiography, dividing the city's documentary past into separate linguistic archives that rarely dialogue with each other", they conclude. Caspar Chan and Nathan Rubene dos Santos also understand that “these volumes offer new answers in historiographical terms, because they show with renewed clarity that the legal existence of Macau emerged through the transplantation and local adaptation of the Portuguese municipality [Évora] as a governing idea on an Asian border”. “At its core, the archive poses a fundamental question that often remains implicit: what counted as ‘Portuguese territory’ in its smallest civic unit, and how could this unit be reconstructed overseas through privileges, positions and jurisdiction, after Portugal had become global from the 15th century onwards?” Local management Regarding the relationship between Portugal and China at the time, the authors state that the work shows how “relations between China and Portugal in Macau were not carried out mainly through formal diplomacy between two distant courts, but through the daily management of coexistence by local institutions, in conditions of unequal jurisdiction”. The first volume of the book shows how “the king elevated Macau from a town to a city and confirmed the elections of councillors, judges and officials because the Captain-Major appointed to China frequently left for the annual trip to Japan, remaining only a short time there and leaving the settlement without continuous leadership”. The original document reveals that “this situation was especially dangerous in China, given Macau's distance from India and the fact that supplies could only be made during the annual trip”. In this way, “municipal government is presented as a necessity: a frontier city could not wait for an absent commander nor could it allow disorder.” Thus, the authors add, “the privileges, jurisdiction and civic positions granted to Macau describe a political logic as much as a legal one, since the Portuguese presence depended on a permanent local body capable of maintaining peace and managing risks in a space where the superior authority was distant”. Regarding the permits, they show what maintaining the stability of the territory entailed, as “the survival of Macau depended on remaining within the limits tolerated by the Chinese authority”. "The Twenty-sixth Alvará, for example, is explicit in stating that the Chinese mandarinate did not accept Portuguese jurisdiction over Chinese subjects, especially when Christian creditors sought to arrest Chinese debtors. The Senate describes the expenses and dangers caused when a mandarin was sent to enforce such determinations and requests a direct solution: preventing Christians from contracting credits with the Chinese and denying them recourse to both the Ombudsman and the Chinese courts, so that the city could 'live in peace’. The Crown confirms this approach”, they conclude.

item.title: Cooperation | Relations between China and Timor-Leste guided by caution, study indicates
item.description: It is certain that, by being part of the “One Belt, One Road” initiative, Timor-Leste can become a strategic point in commercial relations on this side of the globe, despite the “cautious pragmatism” in relations with China. The conclusion is a study on Timorese foreign policy within the scope of the Chinese initiative, authored by three Portuguese academics Timor-Leste, a young country, has been cementing its relations with China, namely through the “One Belt, One Road” initiative, but there is still some caution surrounding this relationship. This is one of the conclusions of the study “Timor-Leste's foreign policy options within the scope of China's Belt and Road 2.0 Initiative: a small state perspective”, authored by academics Tiago Botelho dos Santos, Diogo Borges and Paulo Afonso Duarte. The work was published in The Pacific Review, an academic journal edited by Taylor & Francis. The research work starts with Timor-Leste's adherence to the Chinese initiative, something that happened in 2017, to analyze how the relationship with China has been going, taking into account the fact that Timor-Leste has “the status of a small state”. It is concluded, therefore, that “Timor-Leste's involvement with China's Belt and Road Initiative, particularly in the post-2023 period, can be understood as a strategic and calculated attempt to maximize its status as a small state in a complex regional and global environment”. It is described that, in this period, Timorese foreign policy has been characterized “by a multi-vector approach, strategically anchored in multilateralism”, seeking to “diversify international partnerships to reinforce national security, promote economic development and expand its voice in the international system”. The study points out that relations between Timor-Leste and China, in the context of the Belt and Road initiative, are a “deliberate movement to leverage development opportunities” in the country, being a strategy aligned with the Timor-Leste Strategic Development Plan 2011-2030. The plan aims to “promote economic diversification and the development of critical infrastructure, in a context in which the Belt and Road 2.0 Initiative emphasizes digital infrastructure, green energy and cooperation in the area of ​​health”. Timorese potential The three academics also highlight that Timor-Leste, as part of the Chinese geopolitical initiative, has the potential to stand out economically, and also in commercial terms, in the region. The country has “the potential to assert itself as a logistical center on a route that connects the South Indian Ocean to the South Pacific”, so the Chinese initiative “offers a relevant opportunity to significantly increase its regional prominence and decisively facilitate” integration into ASEAN [Association of Southeast Asian Nations], to which Timor-Leste recently joined. Despite all these positive signs, the study concludes that “although Timor-Leste's relationship with China has deepened, culminating in a comprehensive strategic partnership in 2024, its engagement continues to be marked by cautious pragmatism”. In this context, “the benefits of greater connectivity and investment are carefully weighed against concerns regarding debt sustainability, transparency and possible strategic dependencies”. This caution on the part of Timor-Leste demonstrates its “capacity for action by selectively engaging in projects aligned with its national interests”, navigating the “complexities of competition between great powers in the Indo-Pacific, while maintaining its commitment to a balanced and diversified foreign policy”. Timorese pragmatism is also evident, according to the study, in the fact that the country “not only optimizes development opportunities, but also reinforces its regional position by meticulously analyzing economic benefits in the face of potential risks”. What is strengthened, “ultimately”, is the “capacity for action as a small State”, highlight the authors. A “remarkable” ability The study in question highlights how Timor-Leste has had “a remarkable capacity for action” in the context of the “One Belt, One Road” initiative, using other small States, such as Sri Lanka, as a point of comparison. Citing other studies, the three academics highlight how “Timor-Leste has demonstrated a more cautious approach than countries like Sri Lanka, which have faced significant concerns about debt sustainability associated with BRI [Belt and Road Initiative] projects, or landlocked states like Laos and coastal nations like Cambodia.” In the case of these Southeast Asian countries, “Chinese loans for emblematic projects, such as railways and highways, have drastically increased external debt and dependence on Beijing”. What we sought to do in this investigation was “to examine the unique position of Timor-Leste, not as a financier, but also not as a victim of a ‘debt trap'”, highlighting “the distinct and valuable form of action capacity of a small State within the scope of the BRI”. The authors highlight that, in the last decade, China “significantly expanded its presence in Southeast Asia” through the “One Belt, One Road” initiative, thereby “expanding its regional influence in the economic, security and political spheres”. In this relationship, Timor-Leste has been “far from being a passive observer”, seeking to “actively engage with China to ensure development benefits”. Timor-Leste sought to “identify an opportunity to align with the long-term objectives” of its Strategic Development Plan 2011-2030, analysts indicate. “Strategically, the country also intends to capitalize on its geographic position in emerging commercial maritime routes, particularly through the establishment of a logistics hub in the South Indian Ocean and the South Pacific, potentially reinforcing its regional role as a new integrated member state of ASEAN”, point out the authors. Timor-Leste seeks to “balance economic gains and potential dependencies”, in a geopolitical context that “includes competition between great powers in the Indo-Pacific, where United States policies, under successive administrations, aim to contain China's regional influence”. In methodological terms, the authors carried out this investigation based on reading official reports, documents that serve as the basis for signed bilateral agreements and government documentation. In addition, interviews were carried out with “experts based in both Europe and Asia”.
