The authors state that they sought to interview academics and diplomats “due to the fact that ordinary citizens are generally unfamiliar with China's global multilateral initiatives, while diplomats tend to be excessively cautious in their statements, as they represent the official position of their state, and not necessarily their personal opinions”. It is therefore understood that academics “tend to offer more balanced and rigorous analyses”. The questions focused on how Timor-Leste, as a small State, has benefited from the Chinese initiative, whether this initiative is compatible with the Timor-Leste Strategic Development Plan 2011-2030, or whether “there are visible dangers of creating dependency” between the two countries, among other issues.

item.title: Elections | Portugal prepares to choose the next President of the Republic
item.description:
Portugal goes to the vote on Sunday to choose the next President of the Republic. Of the 11 candidates, only two have representatives from Macau: Bessa Almeida from the PSD, and Neto Valente from the PS. The former president of the Macau Lawyers Association highlights that António José Seguro “does not join in provocations against China”, while Bessa Almeida considers that Marques Mendes is the right man for the moment
Eleven candidates will vote on Sunday to choose the next President of the Portuguese Republic, for a five-year term. This is a record number, with only seven having the support of political parties. Running for the position is Luís Marques Mendes, supported by the Social Democratic Party (PSD), and who appointed António Bessa Almeida as his representative in the Macao SAR. Next comes António José Seguro, with the support of the Socialist Party (PS), which has Jorge Neto Valente, president of the Macau Portuguese School Foundation and lawyer, as his representative. They are the only candidates for the Presidency of the Republic who chose figures as representatives of the Macao SAR. The remaining candidates are Henrique Gouveia e Melo, João Cotrim de Figueiredo, Catarina Martins, António Filipe, André Ventura Jorge Pinto, Manuel João Vieira, André Pestana and Humberto Correia. To HM, António Bessa Almeida, PSD activist and explained the reasons for supporting Marques Mendes. “At the time Portugal is going through, the country needs a candidate like Marques Mendes, who has a deep understanding of the different policies”, he began by pointing out. Asked about the type of actions developed in Macau to attract the electorate to vote for Marques Mendes, Bessa Almeida simply mentioned that “the campaign in Macau is totally different from that in Portugal”, and the actions developed involve “what the candidate does in close proximity to the people, passing on information”. For Bessa Almeida, “the electorate in Macau, on the Chinese side, is also made up of Portuguese”, and that “they have been following these elections like any other Portuguese, with confident visions for the future of Portugal”. On January 6th, the president released a note highlighting the importance of Marques Mendes' candidacy, who is currently far from the top spots in the polls. "We have always been concerned with everything related to Portugal and at this moment, at a global level, political changes are sudden and unexpected. That is why we need a visionary president, experienced and thoughtful in guiding the destinies of Portugal and Portuguese people born and living outside the country."
A safe return In Portugal, polls relating to the presidential elections have taken place almost daily, and show a change in the choice of candidates. If initially António José Seguro was somewhat removed from the top positions, a survey carried out by the Universidade Católica Portuguesa for RTP, Antena 1 and the Público newspaper, between the 6th and 9th of January and released this week, shows how Seguro is in a technical tie with André Ventura, Chega's candidate, guaranteeing 23 percent of voting intentions, when Ventura collects 24 percent. João Cotrim de Figueiredo comes in third place, with 19 percent, with the possibility of going to the second round of elections, followed by Marques Mendes and Gouveia e Melo with 14 percent. Another survey, this time for TVI, CNN, TSF and Jornal de Notícias, with data collected on the 10th, 11th and 12th of January, shows Seguro with 23.9 percent of voting intentions, followed by Cotrim de Figueiredo with 20.8 percent and Ventura with 20.5 percent. Marques Mendes falls to fifth place, with 13.2 percent. Seguro chose, in the Macao SAR, Jorge Neto Valente as his agent, who did not answer HM's call. In a statement published in the newspapers this Wednesday, the former president of the Macau Lawyers Association declared that Seguro “proposes a vision of the future based on the modernization of the country, the valorization of education and a commitment to innovation”. Referring specifically to Portugal-China relations, Neto Valente highlights that “unlike other candidates, Seguro does not support China's provocations regarding the status of Taiwan, and is also a candidate who “knows Portugal, Europe and the world”. Neto Valente also stated that Seguro “is a decent man”. “He participated in all debates, showed politeness, defended his ideas firmly, was never excessive in his language and, unlike others, did not insult opponents or make malicious insinuations toward them.”
A “consistent course” Paulo Pisco, leader of the Insurance campaign for emigration, reminded HM that the candidate “even expressed the opinion that, given that it was an in-person vote [for the presidential elections], the Government could have done much more, namely complying with what the electoral law for the Presidency of the Republic says, which is the possibility of opening more polling stations”. Seguro also defended, according to Paulo Pisco, “that mobility voting could also have been applied, based on the experience previously carried out in the last elections for the European Parliament”. Paulo Pisco states that António José Seguro has followed a “very consistent, solid and objective path”, which has allowed him to reach the top of the polls. Regarding the emigrated electorate, the deputy highlights that Seguro “has not deviated from the purposes, form and values ​​with which he intends to exercise the Presidency of the Republic”. Furthermore, it is “a guarantor of the stability of the political system and also of democracy”. “This image that the candidate António José Seguro has shown throughout his career has earned him greater receptivity from voters”, highlighted Paulo Pisco. The president does not forget that “Seguro is the candidate who has the most representatives per country in our diaspora”. "There are 18, ten in Europe and eight outside Europe. I believe that this substantiates a very firm commitment from the candidate to the exercise of his functions as President of the Republic, and to the relationship he intends to have with the diaspora", he stressed. Looking at the candidates lower down in the polls, we have many faces from the left. The same survey with data collected on the 10th, 11th and 12th of January places Catarina Martins, from Bloco de Esquerda, with 2.5 percent; followed by António Filipe, from PCP, with 1.4 percent, head to head with Jorge Pinto, from Livre, who has 1.3 percent. Manuel João Vieira, visual artist and musician, obtains 1 percent of voting intentions.

item.title: Study | Hong Kong society dominates depression news
item.description: A study published in the Journal of Medical Internet Research analyzed the themes and emotional tone of news stories about depression published in Hong Kong. The “societal system”, related to health, family or work, comes first with 34.83 percent of total news, having a “more negative inclination” The Hong Kong society system dominates the group of topics present in news about depression, representing 34.83 percent of the articles analyzed, followed by topics such as law enforcement, with 18.81 percent, or the global economic recession in third place. This is the main conclusion of the study “Analyzing Themes, Feelings, and Coping Strategies Regarding Online News Coverage of Depression in Hong Kong: Mixed Methods Study”, published in the Journal of Medical Internet Research last year. The study was authored by Chen Sihui, Cindy Sing and Yangna Hu, from Hong Kong Polytechnic University; and Cecília Cheng, from the University of Hong Kong. The study is focused on online news coverage about depression in the neighboring region, namely from publications such as the South China Morning Post and Hong Kong Free Press, and sought to understand the dominant themes and the emotional charge of the texts, whether they were positive or negative, among other issues. Thus, the study reveals that the region's “societal system” was at the origin of 34.83 percent of news about depression, that is, 848 out of a total of 2,435, followed by the theme of “law enforcement”, representing 458 of all news analyzed, with a share of 18.81 percent. This is followed, in third place, by the theme of “global recession”, with 17.4 percent of responses; “lifestyle”, with 8.05 percent; “leisure”, with 11.21 percent of responses; “health issues”, with 6.94 percent and, finally, “United States politics”, representing just 3.12 percent of the news. The study therefore describes that analyzing the sentiment inherent to the news, “it becomes evident that the societal system presented a more negative inclination”, being “related to several systems of Hong Kong society, including health, social, family, education and work”. Between extradition and covid-19 The collection of online news was carried out between February 2019 and May 2024 “with the aim of examining the most recent representation of depression, especially during and after the period of social unrest and the covid-19 pandemic”. The articles were chosen based on three criteria, one of which was accessibility to readers without a paid subscription, in addition to the fact that the website in question “should allow the retrieval of a sufficient quantity of depression-related news (i.e., more than 20) to ensure adequate data for subsequent analyses.” Websites with news in English were also chosen. Then, separate searches were carried out using the keywords “depression” and “depressed”. The dates chosen for this study relate to two events. One of them was in February 2019, with the introduction of the proposed law on extradition to China, entitled “Fugitive Offenders and Mutual Legal Assistance in Criminal Matters Legislation (Amendment)”. This “triggered protests and marches in Hong Kong due to political differences, leading to a significant increase in cases of depression, worsened in 2020 with the outbreak of Covid-19”. The authors reveal that there were “peaks in coverage” of news related to depression, namely in April and May 2020 and in July 2023. Covid-19 followed as a second occurrence. In the case of news from 2020, the study finds that “confinement measures due to covid-19 strongly affected Hong Kong, contributing to a more depressive mood”, and this period “corresponded to the second wave of the covid-19 outbreak”. The second pandemic wave led to strong confinement measures such as the closure of schools, “remote work policies and the ban on in-person meals in restaurants”. The closure of schools, “as reported in the news, resulted in increased rates of depression among children and anxiety among parents, who had to simultaneously care for their children and elderly people at home.” “In addition, conflicts between work and family also intensified due to the interruption of the normal work routine”, namely “the absence of office space and unclear working hours”, which “was associated with depressive feelings”, it is described. In turn, in 2023 there was an “increase in reported suicide cases”, especially because Coco Lee, “an influential star who faced depression, died by suicide at home, which generated greater awareness about the need to expand support services in the area of ​​mental health and improve accessibility, with helplines frequently being highlighted”. A certain stigma With regard to the second most common topic found in the news, “law enforcement”, the study highlights that it also causes “a negative feeling”. “The volume of news reached peaks in November 2020 and August 2019”, and in 2020, “individual crimes and legal proceedings were mainly reported, with emphasis on the case of a Hong Kong teacher who murdered his wife, which may have caused a great social shock and public attention”. The authors explain that, in this case, “depression was frequently cited in the news as an explanation for the perpetrator's illegal actions, which can reinforce stigmatizing attitudes and portray people with depression as violent, dangerous and more likely to commit crimes”. Other topics that also showed “negative trends” are “health issues” and “United States politics”, with topics such as “lifestyle” or “leisure” “tending towards more positive feelings”. With regard to another theme associated with news about depression, that of the “global recession”, the focus is the “economic difficulties caused by the spread of covid-19 in different sectors”, presenting “a more contradictory positive feeling”. In other words, “the structure of the reports initially described the economic challenges, to then emphasize the initiatives to facilitate recovery in response to the crisis”. Thus, the authors note that “a significant change in general sentiment was observed”, as “until January 2021, the continuous decrease in the amount of positive news was interrupted”, and that afterwards “the aggregate number of positive news exceeded that of negative news almost every month, signaling a general change from a negative feeling to a more positive feeling in relation to the economic circumstances discussed”. The authors consider that the change may be due “to the fact that people have been forced to adapt to a ‘new normal’ and begin the recovery of the economy, health, and society after a year of living with the pandemic”. Regarding the theme of US politics found in news associated with depression, the texts “emphasized rivalry and the presidential electoral process, as well as politicians from different parties who experienced depression”. Few institutional responses The study also looked at so-called coping strategies, that is, cognitive or behavioral efforts used to deal with less good situations. And here, the news analyzed focused mainly on “information about skills and resources” available to help people with depression, such as “support lines for suicidal intentions and suicide prevention”. Mental health programs provided by local organizations were also presented, such as Mind HK, the Kely Support Group and the Mental Health Association of Hong Kong, and articles were written about “counseling services and therapies for people with depression”, or even physical exercise recommendations. The authors highlight that, when analyzing the news, they noticed “the insufficiency of political interventions, institutional support and financial assistance for individuals with depression, which indicates a deficiency at the societal level of coping strategies and which are present in journalistic coverage”.

item.title: Higher education | Academic highlights growth of the sector in Macau
item.description: In “Macau, networks, dialogues and affections – The consolidation of the Portuguese-speaking community of China studies”, academic Pedro Steenhagen argues that Macau is taking great strides to be a bridge at an academic level with Portuguese-speaking countries, despite “still having a long way to go to achieve its goals” The article “Macau, networks, dialogues and affections – The consolidation of the Portuguese-speaking community of China studies”, written by academic and doctoral student Pedro Steenhagen, has just been published in Revista Sinóptica, an editorial project of the Observa China portal. The article highlights the role that the Macao SAR can play in connecting its higher education system with Portuguese-speaking countries, and the growing importance it has had in this area. “The aforementioned efforts in the field of education are not just rhetorical”, he described in the article, noting that “in relatively few decades, the Asian nation has become a true power in the area”. Pedro Steenhagen is based on two world rankings to assess the quality of higher education in the world, namely the World University Rankings 2026 by Times Higher Education (from 2025), which shows how “Macau, a small special administrative region in China, has three ranked universities: University of Macau (145), University of Science and Technology of Macau (251-300) and University of the City of Macau (601-800)”, these data being related to positions occupied in the ranking. “Very interestingly, MSAR universities have experienced tremendous growth; for example, the University of Macau has seen a jump of more than 250 positions in the ranking in the last 10 years”, highlights the author of the article. In his view, these data translate into the fact that Macao SAR “assumes an increasingly relevant leadership role in the area of ​​education and research”. Furthermore, it has “the best university in the Portuguese-speaking world in its territory, is experiencing an intense expansion of the education and research sector and serves as a fundamental axis for the exchange of people and the promotion of knowledge”. Taking the rankings into account, Pedro Steenhagen's article recalls that China “has five [universities] in the top 50 in the world: Tsinghua University (12), Beijing University (13), Fudan University (36), Zhejiang University (39) and Shanghai Jiaotong University (40)”, with the Times Higher Education ranking “showing a total of 97 results for mainland China”. Brazil, as “the largest Portuguese-speaking country on the globe, has a total of 59 results, and its five best universities are: University of São Paulo (201-250), State University of Campinas (351-400), Federal University of Rio de Janeiro (601-800), Universidade Estadual Paulista (601-800) and Federal University of Rio Grande do Sul (601-800)”. In the case of Portugal, there are 16 results, with the five best higher education establishments being the University of Coimbra, University of Lisbon, University of Porto, Universidade Nova de Lisboa and ISCTE-Instituto Universitário de Lisboa. Looking at the remaining Portuguese-speaking countries, Pedro Steenhagen highlights how “Mozambique has only one presence in the ranking”, with Eduardo Mondlane University, while “no other Portuguese-speaking country has ranked universities”. A long way Despite the good results, Pedro Steenhagen points out that “the Macao SAR still has a long way to go to achieve all its goals”. However, “its enormous potential as a regional and global protagonist in areas such as technology and innovation, sustainable tourism, creative industry, finance and, particularly, teaching, research and people exchange is already quite clear”. The academic article refers to the “Lusophony component and the unique connection with the PLPs [Portuguese-speaking countries] which adds even more dynamism to its ambitions and to a trajectory that can already be considered incredibly successful since its retrocession”, that is, the transition of the Portuguese administration of Macau to China, in 1999. In the case of the University of Macau (UM), the first to emerge in Macau, and which is now celebrating 45 years of existence, “it has the largest Portuguese department in Asia”, it is highlighted in the article, in addition to having “two research centers: the Research Center for Portuguese-Asian Studies and the Chinese-Portuguese Bilingual Teaching and Training Center”, with “its growing internationalization movement being notable”. Pedro Steenhagen counts the “student exchange programs with more than 10 Brazilian universities”, in addition to the strengthening of “collaboration in teaching and research via international alliances, such as the Association of Portuguese Language Universities, and the establishment of the Center for Judicial and Legal Studies of China and Portuguese-speaking Countries”. The example of the City University of Macau (UCM) is mentioned, where the Institute for Research on Portuguese-Speaking Countries is established, with “unique programs” of master's and doctoral degrees in Studies of Portuguese-Speaking Countries. By establishing partnerships with ISCTE-IUL, UCM is in a “position at the forefront of academic programs and initiatives that go beyond purely linguistic and cultural issues” in connection with Portuguese-speaking countries. There is also the example of a private higher education institution, the University of São José, which “signed [agreements], for example, with the Federal University of Ceará and the Portuguese Catholic University, not only to bring closer relations on a bilateral basis, but also to promote joint projects”. The place of the Government Pedro Steenhagen also refers to the intervention of the Macao SAR Government in connecting with the Portuguese-speaking world, namely the Directorate of Economic and Technological Development Services and the Macau Business Incubation Center for Young People, which have held the Macau Innovation and Entrepreneurship Competition for Technology Companies from Brazil and Portugal since 2021. Of note is the Macau Scientific and Cultural Center (CCCM) in Lisbon and the Macau Houses spread around the world which, “together with international initiatives such as the Meeting of Macanese Communities, contribute not only to the vitality of intellectual exchanges, but also to the cultivation of memory and affective ties between Macau, the diaspora, descendants and Portuguese-speaking communities”. “Associations such as the Association of Brazilian Studies in Macau and the Industrial and Commercial Association of Macau offer substance, in a complementary way to universities and research institutes, for strengthening relationships, developing networks and generating increasingly fruitful dialogues between the parties involved”, it further reads. Pedro Steenhagen is a doctoral candidate in the field of International Politics at the School of International Relations and Public Affairs at Fudan University, and president of the Brazilian Citizens' Council in Shanghai. On the Observa China platform, he is development director and coordinator of the China-Brazil and Lusofonia Relations Center. The platform is a think-tank created in 2020 by “a group of young professionals and students with the mission of creating a network to qualify the debate on China in Portuguese”, reads the website.

item.title: Food safety | Requests for improvements in supervision
item.description: The assemblyman linked to the Fujian community is concerned about the transport of food in the case of food platforms and also the most recent recalls of baby products Following cases of baby products being withdrawn from the market and reports of food poisoning in local luxury restaurants, MP Chan Lai Kei wants the Government to strengthen food supervision. The request is contained in a written interpellation, released yesterday. According to the deputy linked to the Fujian community, although the Institute for Municipal Affairs (IAM) announced that last year the general approval rate for inspections carried out through food sampling was 99 percent, food safety faces more and new challenges. In relation to baby products, taking into account the recent cases of food recalls, such as powdered milk, the deputy wants to know whether the authorities will be more demanding in providing information on the origin and route of the items. “Neighboring regions have already established a ‘baby food tracking labeling system,’ requiring importers to provide full information about the production chain so that parents can check the food’s journey via a QR code,” Chan wrote. “Will the IAM move forward with the establishment of a ‘special supervision plan for children’s foods’, implementing more frequent tests for powdered milk and children’s complementary foods, as well as regularly publishing the safety levels of brands?”, he asked. Dangers of take-away Other challenges arise associated with the progressive increase in the number of visitors and a new culture of take-away not only for food, but also for drinks. According to Chan, the number of orders on take-away platforms continues to rise every year. However, during transport and waiting times, the deputy indicates that there is no temperature control or hygiene regulations, due to “regulatory gaps”. This is an aspect that the deputy hopes to see changed: “How will the authorities reinforce interdepartmental cooperation, and formulate mandatory standards for the hygiene of take-away boxes, time limits for delivery and separation of packaging when transporting hot and cold food […]?” question. Chan Lai Kei also suggests using digital methods to remotely control food, with random inspections. In the document, the legislator also points out that Macau welcomes more than 40 million visitors annually, and that banquets and festivals are frequent, which increases food risks. For this reason, Chan Lai Kei suggests that the Government draw up a food safety response plan during the peak tourism season so that it can quickly trace the origin of any poisoning.

item.title: Presidential | Seguro wins elections in Macau and nationally
item.description: The former leader of the Socialist Party will be the future President of the Republic of Portugal, succeeding Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa. When 20 parishes still needed to be counted, where the elections were postponed due to bad weather, Seguro collected 66.82 percent of the votes António José Seguro was the winner of the elections and will be the future President of the Republic of Portugal, after having achieved 66.82 percent of the votes (3.4 million votes), against André Ventura's 33.18 percent (1.7 million votes). The candidate linked to the Socialist Party also won in Macau, where he obtained 68.53 percent of the votes, against 31.47 percent for the candidate supported by Chega. In relation to the territory, a total of 1,403 voters were counted, with Seguro collecting 934 votes and Ventura 429 votes. There were also 32 blank votes (2.28 percent) and eight invalid votes (0.57 percent). The results show that there were 971 fewer people voting in the second round in Macau than in the first, when 2,374 votes had been recorded. The abstention rate for the second round among the 57,748 voters reached 97.45 percent, with those voting at 2.43 percent. In the first round, Luís Marques Mendes, a candidate supported by the Social Democratic Party, received the most votes and received 1,073 votes, a figure above that which now contributed to guaranteeing the presidency to António José Seguro. In the first vote, the participation rate was 4.11 percent, which represented an abstention of 95.98 percent. In this round of voting, António José Seguro came in second place, with 477 votes and André Ventura in third, with 282 votes. China was safe Yesterday's results were provisional, as there were still 20 parishes to be counted in Portugal and seven “consulates” abroad. Among the so-called “consulates” by the National Elections Commission, the results from Beijing remained to be determined. However, the votes from Macau combined with those from Shanghai gave Seguro victory, with 944 votes, against Ventura's 432. In Shanghai, Seguro obtained 10 votes, against three for Ventura, with no blank or invalid votes being recorded. Despite the results in China, Ventura managed to be the most voted abroad with 51.88 percent of the votes (42,265) against 48.12 percent for Seguro (39,208), while blank votes were 1.21 percent and invalid votes were 0.65 percent. “Working for Portugal” In his victory speech, António José Seguro promised to work to develop the country and presented himself as the “president of all Portuguese”, even those who did not vote for him. “As the future President of the Republic, I add that from tonight onwards we are no longer adversaries and we now have a shared duty to work for a more developed and fairer Portugal”, stated the winner of the night, in a speech given in Caldas da Rainha. “The majority that elected me disappears tonight [Sunday]”, he added. 2nd round of presidential elections in Macau Candidate Percentage of Votes Total Votes António José Seguro 68.53% 934 votes André Ventura 31.47% 429 votes Voters 2.43% Abstention 97.57% 1,403 voters 57,748 subscribers

item.title: UTM | Cultural consultancy and promotion company created
item.description: The Macau Tourism University (UTM) has created a new company that will dedicate itself to consulting in areas such as tourism, culture, research, training courses and even commercial investment management. The company was named Cultural and Tourism Development of the Macau Tourism University and the information appears on the website of the Public Assets Supervision and Management Services Department. UTM is the only shareholder, with a share of 500 thousand patacas. The Board of Directors is constituted, by choice of Sam Hou Fai, by Diamantina Luíza do Rosário Sá Coimbra, as president, Fátima Henrique Boyol Ngan and Cindia Lam, who perform the functions on a combined basis. Lau Vai Lan is the sole inspector and will receive 56,400 patacas per year. The remaining members of the board of directors do not have a fixed remuneration.

item.title: National security | Calvin Chui defends new law
item.description: Calvin Chui, lawyer and president of the Macau Youth Federation, defended the Government's proposed law that will allow judicial representatives to be removed from any process that has elements understood to be relevant to national security. “The transformation [of the diploma] into a concrete legal system and the improvement of the high-level ‘architecture’ of the national security operating structure are in line with the fundamental requirements of Macau’s governance, in accordance with the law”, said Chui, son of deputy Chu Sai Peng and nephew of former Chief Executive Chui Sai ON, in statements cited by Canal Macau. “This approach also promotes the rule of law and the institutionalization and normalization of national security work, with the ultimate aim of establishing a more robust and stable legal safeguard for the long-term stability and sustained prosperity of the Macao SAR,” he added. According to the future requirements of the diploma that will still be voted on in the Legislative Assembly, the commission will have all the powers to veto the participation of lawyers in cases. In addition, judicial representatives must present detailed information about their lives, connections with the outside world and also their household.

item.title: Parenting | Government rejects calls to reinforce the license
item.description: The Macau Government yesterday rejected calls to increase paternity leave, despite the region intending to reinforce maternity leave and annual leave, to reverse the lowest birth rate in the world. In the first session of a public consultation, representatives of two of the most important traditional associations in the territory defended the extension of paternity leave, currently set at just five working days. A leader from the General Union of Residents' Associations of Macau said that paternity leave should be extended up to 15 days or, alternatively, part of the leave could be taken by the father. The representative, surnamed Sit, argued that the measure could help the father to take a more active role, particularly in the first months of the baby's life, especially if the mother is still recovering from a cesarean section. A representative of the General Association of Women of Macau also called for the strengthening of paternity leave, to encourage fathers to take care of their children and “promote gender equality”. But Maria Chu Pui Man, director of the Directorate of Labor Affairs Services (DSAL), rejected the appeals and said only that the father could, as is currently the case, take days off to support the family after the birth. The public consultation, running until March 16, is based on a proposal from DSAL to extend maternity leave in the private sector from 70 to 90 days – an amount already applied to public administration employees – with the costs to be shared between the Government and employers. Vacations on the agenda The authorities also want to increase annual leave in the private sector, based on seniority. For 40 years, permanent residents of Macau have been entitled to just six paid days of rest annually. Civil servants are entitled to 22 working days. The territory's Executive proposes that workers have the right to one more working day of vacation for every two years they spend in the same company, up to a maximum of 12 working days per year. One of the objectives of the changes, said DSAL director Chan Un Tong on January 30, is to allow the population of Macau “to achieve a better balance between work and family life”. In 2025, the Government commissioned a study “from a third entity” – whose identity was not revealed – on the possible increase in maternity leave and annual leave, which was completed at the end of the year. The study included a survey, according to which workers consider both the current maternity leave and the annual leave period “insufficient to meet family needs”. World leaders Asked by Lusa about the potential impact of changes in the birth rate in Macau, which in 2024 was the lowest in the world, Chan Un Tong replied that the objective is to “improve workers’ right to rest”. In 2025, Macau registered 2,871 newborns, a drop of 20.4 percent and the lowest number of births in almost 50 years, said on January 1, the deputy director of Centro Hospitalar Conde de São Januário, Tai Wa Hou. Macau recorded just 0.58 births per woman in 2024, far from the value needed to replace generations (2.1), the lowest fertility rate ever in the region and the lowest in the world, according to official data. This value is even lower than the estimate made in a report released in July by the United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs (UNDESA): 0.68 births per woman. Although more optimistic, the UNDESA estimate already indicated that Macau would have the lowest birth rate in the world in 2024, a long way from the second jurisdiction on the list, Singapore, with 0.95 births per woman.

item.title: Mental Health | Deputies ask for better monitoring of students
item.description: With the number of requests for help from students rising, deputies Lam Lon Wai and Loi I Weng want more commitment from the Government to improve mental health, and call for the use of artificial intelligence Deputies Lam Lon Wai and Loi I Weng advocate the use of newer technologies, mainly artificial intelligence, to monitor the mental health of young people in Macau. This is how legislators reacted to the most recent data published by the Juvenile Monitoring Section of the Judicial Police. According to authorities, last year 250 requests for assistance were made by minors with symptoms of emotional disturbance or stress, which corresponded to an increase of 64 percent year on year. The increase was the sharpest in the Macao SAR since there are records. In a statement, Lam Lon Wai, who is also deputy director of the Secondary School for Workers' Sons and Brothers, argued that to ensure the healthy growth of students, it is necessary to establish a cooperation mechanism between family, school, Government and society. The deputy stated that the family is the first line of defense, so parents should pay more attention to their children's changes in mood, their friendships, and internet use, particularly during long holidays. The deputy director also indicated that parents must monitor their children very closely to identify signs of risk. Role of schools Furthermore, Lam Lon Wai pointed out that schools must continue to invest in education for life, mental health and legal education for young people, so that students develop correct values, as members of society. From Lam's perspective, this role must be complemented by the Government and society by strengthening support for mental health and developing help channels. Promotion must use social media to be more comprehensive. For her part, the deputy and also deputy director of the General Women's Association School, Loi I Weng, argues that the Government should use artificial intelligence to monitor the mental health of young people in schools, through data collection and analysis, to identify and intervene in potential cases. The official also hopes that the Government will provide schools with more resources to alleviate the workload of assistants who are on the front line and to increase the quality and effectiveness of these monitoring services. The issue of mental health gained predominance during the pandemic and post-pandemic years, with data growing steadily. Authorities dealt with this increase by opting out of releasing statistics.

item.title: Research | Epstein and Bannon discussed Wynn and Adelson’s “weaknesses”
item.description: Macau appears in more than 200 files in the “Epstein Library”, mostly in articles relating to casino revenue and the investment environment. However, conversations with Steve Bannon emerge about Trump's lack of respect towards Steve Wynn and Sheldon Adelson, as well as notes from a sexual predator about a visit to Macau With millions of files still to be released, and with the last update made last Friday, Macau appears in 208 files in the so-called “Epstein Library” on the US Department of Justice portal. Throughout the more than two hundred files, references to Macau are divided between innocuous invitations to open art exhibitions resulting from artistic residencies in the Macao SAR, “briefings” with economic news and about Sheldon Adelson's business in Macau, sent by dubious characters to say the least, reports on the business environment and gambling revenues and trips to the territory. HM analyzed the files released so far, diving between purely financial information and sordid allusions. One of the most interesting conversations, dated January 1, 2019, features Jeffrey Epstein himself and political operative and podcaster Steve Bannon. Among political contiguities, Epstein states that the American Democratic Party would be using a law that requires registration as a foreign agent to attack Steve Wynn. A tactic described as “potent”. And then he says that “Donald doesn't respect him at all, nothing at all”, referring to the founder of Wynn Resorts. After Bannon's agreement, Epstein continues to state: “the same in relation to Adelson”, adding the fragile position of those who have “interests in Macau”. "Way worse than fragile, buried in shit. They already threw your contact from a 40-story building," adds Bannon. The MAGA movement operative and strategist in Trump's first term as President of the United States does not specify who was “thrown” from the building, but the conversation between Bannon and Epstein took place just over two months after the alleged suicide of Zheng Xiaosong, director of the Central Government Liaison Office in Macau. Zheng died after falling from Block 2 of the Hung On Center, on Rua de Luís Gonzaga Gomes. Beijing issued a short statement stating that he was suffering from depression, suggesting that it was a case of suicide. Remember that at this time Jeffrey Epstein had already been convicted of crimes of a sexual nature and Steve Bannon was “helping” the tycoon to rehabilitate his public image, in the midst of the campaign for the elections won by Joe Biden. Macau, an inspiration Still in the conversation between Steve Bannon and Epstein, it is indicated that Steve Wynn has a “huge problem with Kwok”, who Epstein refers to as “your boy”. According to the Justice Department's investigation into Steve Wynn, in 2022 during the Biden Administration, Bannon's “boy” will be Miles Kwok, or Guo Wengui, a Chinese dissident businessman exiled in the United States. The founder of Wynn Resorts reportedly tried to influence the White House in 2017, during Donald Trump's first term, to repatriate Miles Kwok to face corruption charges in China. Despite Trump's alleged disrespect towards Wynn and Adelson, the two gambling businessmen contributed many millions of dollars to the campaigns of the current President of the United States. From a much lighter perspective, on a scale of weak morality, in April 2014, Jeffrey Epstein receives an email from his long-time assistant Lesleu Groff with an invitation to the opening of the exhibition “Classic Artwork from Macau”, at the New York Academic of Art. The exhibition was the result of an invitation from the Macao SAR Government, through the Directorate of Tourism Services, to 10 artists based in the United States. The idea would be to take advantage of an artistic residency in the territory to capture the beauty of Macau. Of the 10 artists chosen, three were students at the New York Academic of Art, an institution that had Epstein in its administration. Despite the lighter perspective of this detail in the files, it is important to note that Epstein's accomplice, Ghislaine Maxwell, recruited victims among the academy's students. In the published files it is not indicated whether Epstein visited the art exhibition inspired by Macau. Rot and finances The vast majority of mentions of Macau in documents released by the Department of Justice concern opinion pieces and financial news about the business environment in Macau, gambling revenue from local dealerships, and articles about Sheldon Adelson's connections to the Republican Party. Most of the emails containing this type of information were sent by an assistant to the deceased sexual predator, but also by other characters. In addition to receiving reports from Deutsche Bank Securities, including on the development of infrastructure in the region (such as the Delta Bridge, Zhuhai's connection to the high-speed rail line and the Light Rail) and its expected impact on Macau's economy, Epstein received articles sent by Terje Rød-Larsen and Sultan Ahmed bin Sulayem with information about the Macao SAR. The first is a Norwegian politician and diplomat, who since leaving public office has dedicated himself to uniting the North American MAGA movement and European far-right parties. Rød-Larsen sent a collection of articles, some of them about Sheldon Adelson. The second is a businessman from the United Arab Emirates, who shared with Epstein sordid details about his sexual adventures with women, but who also sent articles about the Macau casino industry. Some emails appear with the emissary erased, with an email from September 2012 in which it is stated that “Macau is becoming super interesting”, in a message about the GDP growth of the Comoros Archipelago, on the southeast coast of Africa. However, in addition to economic and political information, in the files in which Macau is mentioned, messages from Jean-Luc Brunel, a sexual predator who operated as the owner of a modeling agency, and who allegedly committed suicide in prison before being tried, appear. The similarities with Epstein's death go further, with hanging allegedly being the method used by both. In December 2013, Brunel told Epstein that he was leaving for Macau, describing the city as “rat hunting territory”. When he arrives, the Frenchman says that “Macau is more horrible than horrible”. However, two days later, Brunel says “Las Vegas looks like a small, chic city”, without punctuation. There are no further details in the files about Jean-Luc Brunel's time in Macau.

item.title: Seat belts (I)
item.description: Hong Kong implemented the “Road Traffic (Safety Equipment Regulation 2025) Amendment” on January 25, which requires all bus passengers to wear seat belts. Violators can face fines of up to HK$55,000 and be sentenced to imprisonment for up to three months. On January 30, just six days after the law came into force, the Hong Kong Government announced its suspension. The amendment will be rewritten before being submitted to the Legislative Council for review. Why was the law suddenly suspended six days after it came into force? The suspension was due to the occurrence of three incidents that gave rise to some reflection on the matter. The first involved a passenger who was unable to unfasten his seat belt and was trapped for around 16 minutes. Twenty firefighters from the Fire Department were sent to help. After carrying out an inspection, Citybus Co. Ltd. discovered that aluminum foil had been placed inside the belt buckle, a suspected act of vandalism, and reported the incident to the police. This case demonstrated the potential risk of mandatory seat belt use during emergency evacuations and raised questions about whether passengers could cut their seat belts to escape in dangerous situations. When reviewing or analyzing a law, it is crucial that there is “clear discernment and careful consideration.” If a passenger needs to escape following an accident and is unable to unfasten their seat belt, do they have the right to cut it to escape? In other words, could the law give people the right to damage other people's property in order to escape? Under Hong Kong law, damaging other people's property is a criminal offence. To convict a suspect, the prosecution will have to prove that the defendant intended to damage someone else's property and demonstrate his actions. If the purpose is to escape during an emergency, even if the belt breaks, there is no malicious intent to damage other people's property, and the person cannot be convicted under criminal law. However, the situation is different with regard to civil law. Civil law establishes lower requirements than criminal law for the concept of “intent,” and in certain circumstances, it may accept the act of damaging another’s property to escape danger as an act to “Avoid an emergency.” Because the law does not explicitly indicate whether passengers can cut their seat belts in these cases, the question arises as to whether passengers have the right to do so to escape and whether they must subsequently compensate the transport company for losses. Furthermore, if the passenger does not compensate the carrier, is the insurance company responsible? Currently, the law does not regulate this issue; To avoid controversy, perhaps future revisions to the law could do so. Without a clear answer in the future, any legislation from the Hong Kong Government will likely be subject to scrutiny. The second incident occurred on January 27th. A passenger in a wheelchair, surnamed Zheng, caught the bus at the Tin Ma Court stop in Wong Tai Sin, Kowloon. Due to mobility problems, he asked the driver for help to fasten his seat belt. During this process, Zheng expressed concern about the way the belt held him, and asked the driver for explanations, which caused a delay in departure. Another passenger named Li, who was in a hurry to get to work, argued with Zheng. When Zheng picked up his cell phone to film the altercation, Li suddenly snatched the device from his hands and repeatedly hit him in the head with the phone. It is believed that this was the first case to involve a person with special needs in a discussion regarding the use of seat belts on a bus and served to draw important lessons. It demonstrates that it is necessary to take special care with people who have special needs when putting on a seat belt. To solve the problem, the driver must first provide help and other passengers will have to be patient. Keeping quiet on public transport can avoid unnecessary conflicts. Ultimately, assisting people with special needs with seat belts and ensuring their safety during travel is an act of care and compassion, similar to providing priority seats. Perhaps the Hong Kong Government could consider including a clause in the legislation to prevent malicious interference from third parties when the driver is helping a passenger to buckle up. This regulation would ensure that people with special needs can access public services, which is certainly consensual. Only by ensuring that those in need receive quick assistance and when possible the bus continues its journey can the problem be resolved. This regulation would benefit everyone. In addition to reviewing the law, transport companies could provide training to drivers related to the mandatory use of seat belts, to learn how to better deal with these situations. They could also place information inside the buses about the provisions made in relation to the transport of people with special needs, ensuring that all passengers were aware. This would also benefit the image of carriers by providing higher quality services, as well as Hong Kong residents and society as a whole. Next week we celebrate Chinese New Year. I wish all my readers a Happy New Year, good health and continued success for Hoje Macau newspaper. We will meet again on February 24th and at that time we will continue our discussion about the use of seat belts on buses. item.title: Calamity
item.description: “I won’t vote even if they arrest me” We went to Portalegre to help some friends who were desperate about the destruction of their homes, like thousands of Portuguese people from North to South. Kristin, Leonardo and last Saturday in Marta, storms that have already caused 15 deaths. Three storms with lots of rain and wind that left Portugal in a state of calamity. Looking closely, it was a rainstorm similar to the many that happen in England and that does not leave thousands of people in despair and without everything they have managed to accumulate throughout a lifetime of work. One difference is that in Portugal government authorities never knew what planning is. Plan what to do in case of a catastrophe, in case of floods, in case of earthquake, in case of a plane crash in Lisbon, in case of purchasing and storing a batch of generators if there is an energy blackout. Planning is a word unknown to those who govern. They worry about day to day life and the announcement of an airport in Alcochete, which should be operational there by the year 2045 and with a TGV from Lisbon to Badajoz. In this last case of the TGV, it would be better if the Government had decided on a TGV between Beja and Lisbon and Beja airport was already operating as Lisbon's international airport. But let's go back to Portalegre and where several Alentejo residents told us, as an act of revolt and despair, similar to Leiria, Marinha Grande, Alcácer do Sal, Ourém, Coimbra or Régua, that “I won't vote even if they arrest me”. In fact, the second round of the presidential elections took place yesterday in most of the national territory, although some municipalities decided to postpone them due to a lack of minimum conditions to open polling stations. The calamity that struck Portugal, some say is unprecedented, has been something horrible. Isolated villages, agricultural fields that disappeared, houses that flew away, hundreds of roofs that disappeared, factories where everything was destroyed and workers were unemployed for many months, thousands of fallen trees, hundreds of cars destroyed, floods of water that invaded houses, hotels and restaurants – some up to the ceiling, displaced homes, exhausted firefighters, a lady cooking in a cubicle for 300 families in a housing unit, marine boats non-stop transporting people who already had a house flooded, animals that were left without stables or kennels, food that did not reach certain populations. There are still thousands of Portuguese people without energy, water and telecommunications. A tragedy that struck a people who never imagined such a catastrophe was possible. However, one very important aspect must be highlighted: solidarity. We remember, for example, the attitude of the people of Trás-os-Montes, particularly in Mirandela, where the Parish Councils got together and acquired tons of tiles that were taken to Marinha Grande in a 16-wheel truck facilitated by the owner. The solidarity between one another has been endless and has been a great display of humanism in the faces of those in government who simply visit the misfortunes experienced by the populations and who tomorrow are already planning their summer holidays in the Algarve or Punta Cana. The first storm Kristin was recorded almost two weeks ago, but state support for those left with nothing may only arrive this week. Insurance companies are starting to “skate” when it comes to putting things in black and white regarding the payment of the losses that each citizen suffered due to the bad weather. Insurance companies should be subject to large fines when they do not comply with stipulations in favor of those affected. They only think about the annual profit… And now? Experts ask about the future, if new Leonardos or Martas continue to appear? The Government must give a quick answer about the future and what it plans to reform so that something changes with positive decisions. And starting with the ‘Civil Protection’ institution, which does not have the humility to admit that its system is full of insufficiencies. It was two weeks of horror, panic, suffering and loss. There were women and men who went more than four days without sleeping an hour. Looking around and just seeing water rising and destroying the refrigerator, the washing machine, the stove, the carpets and all the material values ​​that decorate a house was something very sad. Televisions showed the tears of men and women who were left with absolutely nothing. The country cannot continue like this, because the country is not poor, what exists are too many thieves.

item.title: Predominance of executive power
item.description: In early 2026, Xia Baolong, the director of the Hong Kong and Macao Work Office of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China and the Hong Kong and Macao Affairs Office of the State Council, spoke at a seminar on the topic of “persisting and improving the predominance of executive power to boost the good governance of Special Administrative Regions”. The audience included the Chief Executives of Hong Kong and Macau, as well as members of the plenary sessions from both regions. According to the “Basic Laws” of both regions, the Chief Executive is responsible to the Central People's Government and his Special Administrative Region. In his speech, Xia Baolong highlighted that "the Chief Executive plays a crucial role and assumes significant responsibilities. He must effectively exercise the powers conferred by law, fully assume the responsibility of leading the Special Administrative Region and manage his 'house' well... striving to build an efficient and competent government." The higher the position, the greater the responsibility. The Chief Executive must assume full responsibility for the Special Administrative Region and needs to form an efficient and well-prepared Government; the responsibility is significant and the task is arduous. How to make the most of the advantages of the predominance of executive power will undoubtedly be the biggest test for the Chief Executives of both regions. The Government exists to “serve the people”, and people's degree of satisfaction and happiness is the criterion that assesses whether performance matches aspirations. If members of the Government (civil servants) cannot obtain the approval of the people, replacing them is a reasonable option. Many members of the Central Government were dismissed or detained for corruption and neglect of duty, demonstrating that no one is above the law. Since the return of Hong Kong and Macau to Chinese sovereignty, both regions have developed and progressed, but there are also limitations. Good governance is not based on empty speeches. What is clearly expressed in Xia's speech is the hope for improving and strengthening governance capacity. Let us remember the terrible fire in Tai Po, Hong Kong, which occurred at the end of last year, which is still being investigated by an independent committee. We do not know how many members of the Government will be held responsible for the incident. Furthermore, the recent measure that requires passengers to wear seat belts on public transport went through a lot of setbacks before it was implemented. For example, how can a pregnant woman be forced to wear a seat belt at the end of her term? How to deal with elderly people who prefer to stand up so they don't wear a seat belt? In Macau, with the promulgation and implementation of Law No. 5/2025 “Law on the Activity of Travel Agencies and the Tourist Guide Profession”, travel agencies are not authorized to provide shuttle bus services to inhabitants of large residential neighborhoods, which makes travel problematic, especially for domestic workers and children. With more than 40 million tourists expected to visit Macau in 2025, the capacity of public transport has been systematically tested. Although the city government has not implemented regulations against overcrowding of these vehicles, passengers continue to board buses at designated exit-only stops. The patience and tolerance of Macau residents are extraordinary, but faced with the popularity of online shopping and in mainland China, stores are emptying across the city. Even after they are renovated, when they open again, the owners are not sure how long their businesses will last. The “2026 Consumer Carnival in the North Zone” initiative demonstrates that the Macau SAR Government still needs to work to achieve good governance. Last year, when Chief Executive Sam Hou Fai invited representatives of the Portuguese and English-speaking media to the annual meal, he highly praised their professionalism, concern for social well-being and supervision of the Government's performance. At the same meeting in 2026, Chief Executive Sam Hou Fai expressed the hope that they would continue to pay attention and support the performance of the Macao SAR Government in its various aspects, reflect the living conditions of the population and offer their valid suggestions. In the context of the predominance of executive power in 2026, the media should not be limited to being an instrument of propaganda or a platform for praise, but rather play the role of advisor, supervisor and partner to help the Macao SAR Government achieve good governance.

item.title: The Little Ice Age and its social implications
item.description: Concern about the sustainability of our planet is not new. According to Professor José Pinto Peixoto1 (1922-1996), in his book “Influence of Man on Climate and Environment”2, mentioning an extract from the Book of Isaiah3, “The Earth is desolate and withered; Heaven and Earth are fading. The Earth is desecrated by its inhabitants, because they transgress the law and violate the right…”. In reality, the harmful action that the species Homo sapiens exerts on nature has intensified since around 10,000 years ago, when the agricultural revolution underwent a great increase, when man largely abandoned his activities as hunter-gatherers. With this quote, Professor JPP intended to illustrate that in ancient times there were people who were concerned about what man could do to our planet. By definition, a prophet is someone who serves as an intermediary between the divine and the people, and this text can be interpreted as a warning about the intensification of aggressions that our species would practice, and which led to the current ecological and climate crisis. Life on our planet is only possible due to a series of circumstances, including the Earth being at a distance from the Sun suitable for the existence of liquid water, a breathable atmosphere and a magnetic field that serves as a protector against electrically charged particles emitted by the Sun (solar wind), which prevents the surface from being reached by part of the radiation that is harmful to life. Since the Earth's atmosphere was formed, its characteristics have always evolved, in terms of composition and meteorological and climatic parameters. Climate change has greatly influenced human history, shaping the behavior of Homo sapiens. They have been one of the main causes of great migrations and, consequently, the emergence of different civilizations. Research in the area of ​​paleoclimatology allows us to conclude that, for millions of years, the climate was characterized by glacial and interglacial periods. During the most recent glaciation, ice invaded large areas of Europe and Asia, causing populations to migrate to lower latitudes. Around 6,000 years ago, the prolonged drought that caused the desertification of the region where the Sahara is located, caused people to flee to the Nile River valley, where a civilization flourished whose testimonies are still a source of admiration and study today. In the last million years there have been approximately six glacial periods. Although we are currently in an interglacial period, there have been shorter periods characterized by relatively low temperatures, such as what is known as the “little ice age”, between the 14th and 19th centuries. There is no unanimity about the beginning, and some historians consider that it began later, in the 16th century. There is, however, consensus that this period was characterized by harsh winters and short summers. The cause of this cooling is still debated today, which could have been a consequence of several natural factors, such as the decrease in solar activity and the increase in the concentration of particles in the atmosphere resulting from volcanic activity and the consequent reduction in radiation reaching the surface. According to some historians, the “little ice age” may have been one of the causes of social upheavals. Thus, in the United States of America, in 1692, a social phenomenon occurred that consisted of collective hysteria on the part of the population of Salem, a town in the State of Massachusetts, which resulted in a series of trials, mostly involving women accused of witchcraft. A succession of years with poor agricultural results and consequent food shortages contributed to the perception of insecurity among the populations of the New England region. Faced with this situation, the collective psychological climate contributed to hundreds of women being treated as scapegoats, some of whom were executed by hanging. This subject has been studied by several historians and served as the subject of plays, literary works and films. The most emblematic work was the play by Arthur Miller (“The Crucible” – 1953), in which the author explored this social phenomenon as a metaphor for McCarthyism, a period in US history between the late 1940s and mid-1950s, characterized by the persecution of alleged communists, inspired by Senator Joseph McCarthy. The author himself was a victim of this persecution. There were several literary works on the same subject, perhaps the most striking being the non-fiction work “The Witches: Salem, 1692” by American writer Stacy Schiff. Arthur Miller's play was adapted by Arthur Miller for the cinema in 1996, and the film was distributed in Portugal with the title “The Witches of Salem”. It was also during the Little Ice Age that great social instability occurred that preceded the start of the French Revolution. Popular dissatisfaction caused by widespread hunger due to successive natural disasters, such as a severe drought in 1788 interrupted by intense hail and hailstorms that caused the loss of a large part of the crops that had resisted. To make matters worse, the winter of 1788/1789 was extremely harsh. The melting of thick layers of snow and ice caused floods and floods the following spring, in much of France, causing serious destruction of infrastructure and almost all of the few crops that remained. Following these meteorological disasters, an outbreak of plague emerged that wiped out many of the animals that had been saved. Hunger resulted from these events and chaos ensued in large urban centers. The summer of 1789 was extremely dry, which contributed to the worsening of the situation. This entire sequence of events, together with the ineffectiveness of Louis XVI's government, contributed to social unrest, which may have constituted a kind of trigger to trigger the French revolution, one of the most notable episodes of which was the Storming of the Bastille, on July 14, 1789. It can be concluded that meteorological phenomena that, as a whole, characterize the climate of a region, contribute greatly to the worsening of social crises. For example, the recent storm that hit Portugal on January 27, 2026 (the Kristin depression, resulting from explosive cyclogenesis) generated, on the part of the affected population, a feeling of unease in relation to political power. Another example was the drought that reached its peak in 2017, which caused serious damage to agriculture, livestock, water resources and a strong environmental impact in terms of forest fires that caused dozens of fatalities. In both cases, the political power was accused, by the affected population, of not having taken the necessary measures to minimize the serious consequences that resulted from these natural disasters. Regardless of governments, natural disasters generally cause, rightly or wrongly, the feeling, on the part of the population, that their consequences could be minimized if more efficient preventive measures had been taken, such as, for example, improving forest management, strengthening infrastructure and more rigorous early weather warnings. Meteorologist References: José Pinto Peixoto – Portuguese academic. He was one of the most distinguished scientists on a global scale in the areas of Meteorology and Climatology. He was affectionately nicknamed JPP by his students and colleagues. Published in 1987 by the State Secretariat for the Environment and Natural Resources. The Prophet Isaiah, one of the writers of the Old Testament, lived between the 8th and 7th centuries BC.

item.title: Book by Rui Leão and Carlotta Bruni launched in Lisbon this week
item.description: This Friday, the 13th, in Lisbon, the launch of the book by local architects Rui Leão and Carlotta Bruni, “Layering The City”, will take place at the Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation. The session starts at 11:30 am and is part of the third International Congress on Colonial and Post-Colonial Landscapes, Architecture, Cities and Work, with a presentation by the authors themselves. “Layering The City” is an investigation into infrastructures and public spaces in Macau, revealing the perspectives that Rui Leão and Carlotta Bruni put into each project they undertake, with a focus on projects such as social housing in the Fai Chi Kei neighborhood, the Barra station and the Intermodal zone, related to the Light Rail. As explained by Rui Leão in an interview with HM, the book is composed “of texts by some critics about our work”, namely Jorge Figueira, and an interview conducted by academic Ana Vaz Milheiro, also author of the preface. In this book, there is the idea of ​​construction in layers, revealing the different perspectives of the two architects in each project they carry out. "There is work brought by each person to the project, which involves responding to the programmed request, what the client asks for, what lives in the alignment plan [of the project], or a series of issues at a civic level, public space or the right to quality of life. There are a series of social dimensions [to take into account to] make spaces for people, even when they are impossible [in terms] of politics and in the city. It is these layers that enter the projects and that, deep down, pass for creating opportunities to improve the life of the city, the person, the street”, said Rui Leão in the same interview. Portuguese houses Meanwhile, architect Rui Leão also participates, as co-curator, in the exhibition “Habitar Portugal 1974-2924″, opened this Wednesday, starting at 7pm, at the Architecture Center – Garagem Sul, at the Centro Cultural de Belém, in Lisbon. This is an initiative that marks 50 years of Democracy through a selection of one hundred works of Portuguese Architecture, built in Portugal and around the world between 1974 and 2024”, with the team of curators Alexandra Saraiva and Célia Gomes. According to the official description of the exhibition, available on the CCB website, what is sought is to look at architecture “as a political gesture; to highlight positions of rupture; to enhance the persistence of memories”. You can see projects such as the Hotel Dom Henrique, in Porto, designed by José Carlos Loureiro, or the Complexo das Amoreiras, by Tomás Taveira. Highlights include works such as the Côa Museum, by Camilo Rebelo and Tiago Pimentel, or the requalification project of Casa do Passal – Museu Aristides de Sousa Mendes, by the studio Rosmaninho + Azevedo. This is the seventh edition of the “Habitar Portugal” exhibition, with one hundred works having been chosen “with different programs and different scales, guided by national and international representation (including the Portuguese expression built outside the country)”. According to the same note, “this is a significant and valuable record that not only offers a panoramic look at the last quarter of the 20th century and the first of the 21st century, but also seeks to project the future of contemporary Portuguese architecture, and consequently the social, economic and territorial development of Portugal in the world”.

item.title: Concert | South Korean group Treasure in Macau next month
item.description: The Venetian Arena is preparing to host, on March 6th, another K-Pop concert, this time by the boy band Treasure. The group from South Korea, made up of ten members, was created in 2019 and was born in the context of a television program made to discover musical talents The band Treasure, from South Korea, has only been alive for a few years, but their success seems to be guaranteed. Proof of this is the group's show that Macau will host on March 6th at the Venetian Arena, in Cotai, from 8pm, as part of the “Treasure Tour [Pulse On] in Macao”. Treasure are a boy band formed in 2019 through the YG Treasure Box talent hunt program, which aimed to train this group of young singers. Of the more than 20 candidates, who had to pass several challenging tests to demonstrate their talent, the ten best voices were chosen. Currently, the group consists of Choi Hyun-suk, Jihoon, Yoshi, Junkyu, Yoon Jae-hyuk, Asahi, Doyoung, Haruto, Park Jeong-woo and So Jung-hwan. The recipe of combining the creation of a group of singing boys with a television program seems to have worked, and the truth is that success was felt as soon as they started composing songs and publishing them on the market. In August 2020, “BOY”, the first single, was released, and “The First Step: Chapter One” was also released that year. This record work was part of a trilogy of albums that, as a whole, sold more than a million copies in just five months. According to the description of the show in Macau, available on the Venetian Arena website, it is said that the concert reveals how Treasure are “expanding their global influence”, as the first tour, just in Japan in 2023, included eight cities and 26 shows. At that time, the tour attracted “almost 300,000 spectators and set the record for the highest audience for a debut tour by a Korean artist”. The first tour in Asia followed, this time with 17 cities included and a total of 40 concerts. In 2024, Japan once again hosted a Treasure tour, which included two meetings with fans, while last year the “Treasure Fan Concert [Special Moment] took place. These moments were also revealing of the group's success, as together they “surpassed an accumulated audience of one million [people], demonstrating their status and the band's power in live performances”. On the road since 2025 Treasure come to Macau with new songs under their belt. The third mini-album, titled “Love Pulse”, was released on September 1st, and in March it was time for the record market to receive “Pleasure”, a “special mini-album”. The concert at the Venetian Arena is part of the group's tour that has marked Treasure's schedule since the second half of 2025. In October, the group gave three consecutive concerts in Seoul, and then performed again in Japan.

item.title: Archive in Lisbon helps Brazilians confirm land ownership
item.description: The Overseas Historical Archive (AHU) of Portugal is still consulted today by Brazilians looking for proof that they are the owners of their lands in Brazil, distributed by the Portuguese five centuries ago, indicates the person responsible for this institution. “From time to time, we receive requests to hand over an authenticated document to a court, or to settle a dispute or conflict at that level, despite it being historical documentation,” Ana Canas, a researcher at the History Center of the University of Lisbon who has served as director of the AHU, told the Lusa agency. This documentation, physically present in the AHU, but already available on digital media, includes documents from the granting of sesmarias in Brazil, a land distribution system adopted by the Portuguese Crown, in the 16th century, in which land was donated to sesmeiros, so that they could occupy and produce on them. And it is this proof of land concession that its owners still seek at the AHU today, as it is there that the documentation resulting from the relationship between Brazil and the Portuguese administration resides, during the colonial period. Kilometers of papers The AHU, created in 1931 with the aim of safeguarding the repositories of the Portuguese colonial administration, stores around 17 kilometers of documentation, which portrays the relationship between the various territories (former Portuguese colonies) and the organizations based in Lisbon. Documents that have proven to be sources of information about these territories and their experiences: India, Brazil, Angola, Cape Verde, Guinea-Bissau, Mozambique, São Tomé and Príncipe, Timor-Leste and Macau. The Brazilian collection, located at the AHU facilities, which is located in the Palácio do Ega, in Lisbon, was the subject of the “Projecto Resgate Barão do Rio Branco”, an international archival cooperation program, whose mission is to catalog and reproduce the handwritten historical documentation relating to this country, until independence, in 1822. The Portuguese arrived in Brazil in 1500 and the occupation of the lands began in 1530. It is the history of this presence and the relationship with the Crown, in Portugal, until independence, that the documentation tells. For more than 10 years, around 120 researchers involved in this project worked on the 300,000 documents that are located at the AHU and that involve Brazil, which are now duly identified and distributed in more than 2,000 boxes, in addition to being available on digital media.

item.title: Concert | OneRepublic perform in Hong Kong this month
item.description: The North American band OneRepublic is returning to Asia for a series of concerts, highlighting their trip to the AsiaWorld-Expo stage on the 17th for the “OneRepublic – From Asia, With Love in Hong Kong” tour. Performances will follow in China, Korea and Japan Asian fans of North Americans OneRepublic will soon have the opportunity to see them up close again. After a visit to Macau in 2024, the group will return to Asia, but this time to neighboring Hong Kong, to perform as part of the “OneRepublic – From Asia, With Love in Hong Kong” tour. This show is scheduled for the 17th of this month at AsiaWorld-Expo. Organized by LiveNation, the concert takes place from 8pm and promises to bring the greatest hits from the band that has already been nominated for a Grammy, namely “Counting Stars”, “Apologize”, “I Ain’t Worried” and “Run”. The synopsis of the show, published on the AsiaWorld-Expo portal, states that the band “continues to captivate millions of fans around the world with their characteristic sound and sincere narratives”, and, during their visit to Hong Kong, fans can expect “an electrifying night of music, energy and connection”, in a collective celebration of “the group's greatest hits and new works”. The “From Asia, With Love” tour aims to be “a special celebration of OneRepublic’s strong connection with its Asian fans, highlighting the region as one of the band’s most passionate audiences”, with Hong Kong “being one of the main stops on this exclusive tour”. After visiting the neighboring region, the band continues their trip, on the 23rd, to Seoul, South Korea; followed by performances in Tokyo, on the 25th, and Kobe, on the 27th. In March, it is OneRepublic's turn to travel to another show taking place in Singapore, on the 2nd; followed by Taipei, Taiwan, on March 4th. Concerts in China follow on April 17th, 19th and 25th in the cities of Shenzhen, Wuhan and Shanghai, respectively. OneRepublic continues to tour the rest of the world, particularly with concerts in Mexico and Europe, in countries such as Italy, Luxembourg, Spain and Scotland. Successes since 2000 OneRepublic emerged in 2002 in Colorado Springs presenting themselves as a group of pop rock and alternative rock songs, starting to be successful on the social network MySpace, which has since disappeared. In 2006, the band managed to sign a contract with the record label Mosley Music Group, releasing their debut album, “Dreaming Out Loud”. At that time they achieved international success, thanks to the single “Apologize”, which featured the contribution of rapper and producer Timbaland; and also the single “Stop and Stare”. This album sold more than three million copies worldwide. After several years of recording and being on the road, OneRepublic participated, in 2022, on the soundtrack of the film that revived the cinema classic “Top Gun”, starring Tom Cruise. On the album that contains all the songs from “Top Gun: Maverick” the band participates with “I Ain’t Worried”, alongside names like Lady Gaga or Lorne Balfe. After the release of “Artificial Paradise” in 2024, the group returned to new songs in December last year with the single “Give Me Something”, made for the game “Arknights Endfield”. This song was produced by band members Ryan Tedder, Brent Kutzle and Simon Oscroft.

item.title: Concerts | Ticket scam embezzles five women
item.description: Five women from the interior of China were allegedly defrauded of more than 18 thousand patacas in a scheme related to concert tickets. According to the Chinese Radio Macau channel, the fraud scheme was similar to all the victims and began with a comment from the alleged fraudster in social media posts made by women who wanted to go to concerts and had difficulty acquiring tickets. One of the victims lost a total of 10,438 patacas, having started by transferring 6,000 patacas as payment for two tickets that the fraudster had arranged. Afterwards, the suspect said that the tickets were already sold out, promising a refund that never happened. The scammer also sent QR codes for victims to contact a fake employee from a financial department who would help with reimbursement, leading victims to transfer more money. In this woman's case, another three thousand patacas were transferred, with the suspect claiming that the operation had not been successful, demanding more payments.
